## Section 2.9 The factor theorem

In Chapter 1 we revised techniques for factorising algebraic expressions.
The factor theorem is a more general technique that can be applied to expressions of higher orders.
Using long division, we can divide $f(x)=x^{3}+3 x^{2}-4 x-12$ by $x+3$ as before.

\$\$

\$\$

Evaluating the function at $x=-3,+2,-2$;

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(-3) & =(-3)^{3}+3(-3)^{2}-4(-3)-12=0 \\
f(-2) & =(-2)^{3}+3(-2)^{2}-4(-2)-12=0 \\
f(2) & =(2)^{3}+3(2)^{2}-4(2)-12=0, \text { as we would expect of every root. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Generalising this for every polynomial $f(x)$; if $f(k)=0$, then $x-k$ is a factor.
Conversely, if $x-k$ is a factor, then $f(k)=0$.

## The Factor Theorem:

If $f(k)=0$, then $(x-k)$ is a factor.
Conversely, if $(x-k)$ is a factor, then $f(k)=0$.
Also, if $(a x-k)$ is a factor, then $f\left(\frac{k}{a}\right)=0$.

## Example 1

Show that $(2 x-3)$ is a factor of $2 x^{3}-5 x^{2}+5 x-3$.
Given $(2 x-3)$ is a factor, then $(2 x-3)=0$ is a root, i.e. $x=\frac{3}{2}$ is a root. If $(2 x-3)$ is a factor, then $f\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)$ must equal 0 .

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(x)=2 x^{3}-5 x^{2}+5 x-3 \\
& f\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)=2\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^{3}-5\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^{2}+5\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)+3=\left(\frac{27}{4}\right)-\left(\frac{45}{4}\right)+\left(\frac{15}{2}\right)-3=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad(2 x-3)$ is a factor of $f(x)=2 x^{3}-5 x^{2}+5 x-3$.

## Example 2

If $(x-2)$ and $(x+1)$ are both factors of $a x^{3}+3 x^{2}-9 x+b$, find the values $a$ and $b$.

If $(x-2)$ is a factor, then $f(2)=0$.
If $(x+1)$ is a factor, then $f(-1)=0$.
(i) $f(2)=a(2)^{3}+3(2)^{2}-9(2)+b=0$
(ii) $f(-1)=a(-1)^{3}+3(-1)^{2}-9(-1)+b=0$
$\Rightarrow a .8+3.4-18+b=0$
$\Rightarrow a(-1)+3.1+9+b=0$
$\Rightarrow 8 a+12-18+b=0$
$\Rightarrow-a+3+9+b=0$
$\Rightarrow 8 a+b=6$
$\Rightarrow-a+b=-12$
Using simultaneous equations,
$\Rightarrow a-b=12$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow 8 a+b & =6 \\
a-b & =12 \\
\hline 9 a & =18 \\
a & =2
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\therefore \quad a=2 \text { and } b=-10 \text {. }
$$

## 1. Factorising cubic expressions

We can now use the factor theorem to factorise higher-order polynomials, e.g. cubic polynomials of the form $f(x)=a x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x+d$ that have at least one integer root.

Using trial and error, we evaluate $f(0), f(1), f(-1), f(2), f(-2), f(3) \ldots$ etc., until we get a value of zero.
This is the integer root.
If $f(-2)=0$, then $(x+2)$ is a factor.
If $f(3)=0$, then $(x-3)$ is a factor.
Dividing by this factor produces a quadratic expression which can be factorised separately using factor pairs or using the quadratic formula.

## Example 3

Factorise $f(x)=2 x^{3}+x^{2}-13 x+6$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(x)=2 x^{3}+x^{2}-13 x+6 \\
& f(0)=0+0-0+6=6 \neq 0 \\
& f(1)=2(1)^{3}+(1)^{2}-13(1)+6=-4 \neq 0 \\
& f(-1)=2(-1)^{3}+(-1)^{2}-13(-1)+6 \\
& \quad=+18 \neq 0 \\
& f(2)=2(2)^{3}+(2)^{2}-13(2)+6=0 \\
& \therefore \quad(x-2) \text { is a factor. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Dividing $2 x^{3}+x^{2}-13 x+6$ by ( $x-2$ ),

$$
\begin{array}{r}
x - 2 \longdiv { 2 x ^ { 2 } + 5 x - 3 } \\
\frac{2 x^{3}+x^{2}-13 x+6}{5 x^{2}}-13 x+6 \\
\frac{5 x^{2}-10 x}{-3 x+6} \\
\frac{-3 x+6}{0+0}
\end{array}
$$

$\Rightarrow$ the factors of $f(x)$ are $(x-2)\left(2 x^{2}+5 x-3\right)$
$\Rightarrow$ the factors of $f(x)$ are $(x-2)(x+3)(2 x-1)$.

## 2. Solving cubic equations

To solve cubic equations of the form $f(x)=a x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x+d=0$, we first find the factors as in the above example and then equate each factor to zero to find the roots(solutions).

## Example 4

Solve the equation $\quad 2 x^{3}-4 x^{2}-22 x+24=0$.

Let $f(x)=2 x^{3}-4 x^{2}-22 x+24$
$\Rightarrow f(0)=2(0)^{3}-4(0)^{2}-22(0)+24=24$
$\Rightarrow f(1)=2(1)^{3}-4(1)^{2}-22(1)+24=0$
$\Rightarrow(x-1)$ is a factor.
The factors are $(x-1)\left(2 x^{2}-2 x-24\right)$
Factorising further ; $(x-1)(2 x+6)(x-4)$
$\therefore f(x)=0 \Rightarrow(x-1)=0 \Rightarrow x=1$.

Dividing we get,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 x^{2}-2 x-24 \\
x-1 & \longdiv { 2 x ^ { 3 } - 4 x ^ { 2 } - 2 2 x + 2 4 } \\
& \frac{2 x^{3}-2 x^{2}}{-2 x^{2}}-22 x+24 \\
& \frac{-2 x^{2}+2 x}{-24 x+24} \\
& \underline{-24 x+24}
\end{aligned}
$$

Also, $(2 x+6)=0 \Rightarrow x=-3$
and $(x-4)=0 \Rightarrow x=4$.
The solutions are $\{1,-3,4\}$

## Section 2.10 Graphs of cubic (and higher order) polynomials

The coefficients of a cubic polynomial $f(x)=a x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x+d$ determine the final shape of each graph. Some important features need to be noted and emphasised.

ICT: Input each of the following functions using a graphics calculator or computer software (e.g. Geogebra). Examine the effect of changing coefficients on the shape of each graph.

Note: The factor form of each function is very suitable in some cases.

1. Three real roots
$f(x)=2 x^{3}-4 x^{2}-22 x+24$
$f(x)=(x-1)(2 x+6)(x-4)$
This graph has three real roots, $-3,1,4$.

As the graph passes through a root, the value of the function changes from
$(-)^{\mathrm{ve}}$ to $(+)^{\mathrm{ve}}$ or $(+)^{\mathrm{ve}}$ to $(-)^{\mathrm{ve}}$.
The graph has two turning points, a local maximum and a local minimum.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-086.jpg?height=550&width=776&top_left_y=234&top_left_x=852)

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x) & =2 x^{3}-4 x^{2}-22 x+24 \\
& =(2 x+6)(x-1)(x-4)
\end{aligned}
$$

2. Three real roots, two of which repeat

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x) & =x^{3}-x^{2}-8 x+12 \\
& =(x+3)(x-2)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

This graph again has three real roots, $-3,2,2$, but one of the roots is repeated.
This graph only crosses the $x$-axis once because of the repeated root.
The graph has two turning points.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-086.jpg?height=553&width=508&top_left_y=992&top_left_x=1118)

$$
\begin{array}{r}
f(x)=x^{3}-x^{2}-8 x+12 \\
=(x+3)(x-2)(x-2) \\
=(x+3)(x-2)^{2}
\end{array}
$$

3. One real, two non-real roots

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x) & =x^{3}-2 x-4 \\
& =(x-2)\left(x^{2}+2 x+2\right) \\
& =(x-2)(x+1-\sqrt{-1})(x+1+\sqrt{-1}) \quad \ldots \text { using the } \\
& \quad \text { quadratic formula }
\end{aligned}
$$

This polynomial has only one real root but two non-real (complex) roots.

It crosses the $x$ - axis once and has two turning points.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-086.jpg?height=406&width=357&top_left_y=1723&top_left_x=1278)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(x)=x^{3}-2 x-4 \\
& \quad=(x-2)\left(x^{2}+2 x+2\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

4. Comparing $f(x)=x^{3}-3 x^{2}+2 x$ and $g(x)=2 x^{3}-6 x^{2}+4 x=2 f(x)$

Both polynomials have the same roots, $x=0,1,2$. $\therefore$ the polynomials have common factors ( $x$ ), $(x-1)$ and $(x-2)$.
But $g(x)$ has an integer factor 2 as well that multiplies each value of the curve, except where the value is zero at the roots.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-087.jpg?height=508&width=943&top_left_y=246&top_left_x=686)

This integer factor acts as an amplification factor.
5. Comparing $f(x)=x^{3}-3 x^{2}+2 x$ and $g(x)=-x^{3}+3 x^{2}-2 x=-f(x)$

Again, both polynomials have the same roots and hence common factors. The graphs are symmetrical across the $x$-axis.

Multiplying by a minus inverts the graph.
6. The graphs of $\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=\boldsymbol{a} \boldsymbol{x}^{\mathbf{3}}$

All the graphs pass through $(0,0)$.
For $a>0$, the graphs are all increasing, and as $a$ increases, the graphs rise more steeply. For $a<0$, the graphs are decreasing.
Note:
(i) If $f(x)=3 x^{3}$ and $g(x)=-3 x^{3}$, $\Rightarrow f(x)=-g(x)$, i.e. $f(x)$ is the reflection of $g(x)$ in the $x$-axis.
(ii) $f(-x)=g(x)$, i.e. $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ reflect each other in the $y$-axis.

Note: There are no local maximum or minimum points as in the previous graphs.

## Summary:

(i) Every cubic polynomial crosses the $x$-axis at least once, i.e has one real root.
(ii) Each root produces a factor of the polynomial.
(iii) If a polynomial has a repeated root with an even power e.g. $(x-2)^{2},(x-3)^{4}$ etc., then the graph touches, but does cross, the $x$-axis at these points.
(iv) If the coefficient of $x^{3}$ is positive, the graph starts below the $x$-axis, i.e. starts with a negative $y$-value and increases with increasing $x$-values.
(v) If the coefficient of $x^{3}$ is negative, the graph starts above the $x$-axis, i.e. starts with a positive $y$-value and decreases with increasing $x$-values.
(vi) Some cubic graphs have local maximum and minimum turning points.
(vii) When forming a polynomial from its roots, check for an integer factor.

## Example 1

By examining the graph, find an expression for this cubic polynomial.
(i) The graph crosses the $x$-axis at $x=-2$.
(ii) $\Rightarrow x=-2$ is a root $\Rightarrow(x+2)$ is a factor.
(iii) The graph touches the $x$-axis at $x=1$.
$\Rightarrow x=1$ is a repeated root
$\Rightarrow(x-1)^{2}$ is a factor.
(iv) The graph may contain an integer factor, i.e. $f(x)=a(x+2)(x-1)^{2}$.

From the sketch of this graph,
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-088.jpg?height=557&width=604&top_left_y=1162&top_left_x=938) when $x=0, f(x)=4$.
$\therefore \quad 4=a(2)(1)^{2}=2 a$
$\therefore \quad a=2$.
$\therefore f(x)=2(x+2)(x-1)^{2}=2 x^{3}-6 x+4$.

## Example 2

The graph of the polynomial $f(x)=a(x+b)(x+c)(x+d)(x+d)$ is given in the diagram. Find the values of $a, b, c$ and $d$.

From the diagram, the roots are $x=-2,-1,3$.
A double root occurs at $x=3$.
Hence the factors are $(x+2),(x+1),(x-3)$ and ( $x-3$ ).
$\therefore f(x)=a(x+2)(x+1)(x-3)(x-3)$.
At $x=0, f(x)=18$.
$\therefore \quad 18=a(0+2)(0+1)(0-3)(0-3)=18 a$
$\therefore a=1$
$\therefore \quad a=1, b=2, c=1, d=-3$.

## Section 3.1 Radian measure

In your study of geometry and trigonometry so far, you will have worked with angles which were measured in degrees. One complete revolution is $360^{\circ}$. However, in more advanced trigonometry and calculus, angles are almost always measured in radians.

The diagram on the right shows an arc AB equal in length to the radius, $r$.

The measure of $\angle \mathrm{AOB}$ is said to be 1 radian.
If the length of the arc AB was $2 r$, then $|\angle \mathrm{AOB}|$ would be 2 radians.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-100.jpg?height=320&width=343&top_left_y=1014&top_left_x=1290)

Radian
A radian is the measure of the angle at the centre of a circle subtended by an arc equal in length to the radius.

Since the circumference of a circle is $2 \pi r$, i.e., $2 \pi$ times the radius, then there are $2 \pi$ radians in one complete revolution.

$$
\begin{array}{rr}
\Rightarrow & 2 \pi \text { radians }=360^{\circ} \\
\Rightarrow & \pi \text { radians }=180^{\circ}
\end{array}
$$

Frequently used angles are given in degrees and radians in the box below:

| Degrees | $0^{\circ}$ | $30^{\circ}$ | $45^{\circ}$ | $60^{\circ}$ | $90^{\circ}$ | $180^{\circ}$ | $270^{\circ}$ | $360^{\circ}$ |
| :--- | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| Radians | 0 | $\frac{\pi}{6}$ | $\frac{\pi}{4}$ | $\frac{\pi}{3}$ | $\frac{\pi}{2}$ | $\pi$ | $\frac{3 \pi}{2}$ | $2 \pi$ |

Since $\pi$ radians $=180^{\circ} \Rightarrow 1$ radian $=\frac{180^{\circ}}{\pi}=57.3^{\circ}$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-100.jpg?height=308&width=333&top_left_y=1819&top_left_x=1300)

## Length of arc - Area of sector

If $l$ is the length of an arc of a circle of radius $r$, then the angle $\theta$ at the centre of the circle is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta \text { radians } & =\frac{l}{r} \\
\Rightarrow \quad l & =r \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-101.jpg?height=324&width=350&top_left_y=168&top_left_x=1287)

Also since area of the circle is $\pi r^{2}$, the area of the sector AOB is

$$
\text { Area }=\frac{\theta}{2 \pi} \times \pi r^{2} \Rightarrow \text { Area }=\frac{\theta r^{2}}{2}=\frac{1}{2} r^{2} \theta
$$

Arc length $l=r \theta$
Area of sector $=\frac{1}{2} r^{2} \theta$

## Example 1

Express (i) $\frac{2 \pi}{5}$ radians in degrees
(ii) $210^{\circ}$ in radians.
(i) $\frac{2 \pi}{5}$ radians $=\frac{2 \times 180^{\circ}}{5}=\frac{360^{\circ}}{5}=72^{\circ}$
(ii) $210^{\circ}$ to radians

$$
\begin{aligned}
180^{\circ} & =\pi \text { radians } \\
\Rightarrow \quad 1^{\circ} & =\frac{\pi}{180} \text { radians } \\
\Rightarrow \quad 210^{\circ} & =\frac{\pi}{180} \times \frac{210}{1} \text { radians } \\
& =\frac{21 \pi}{18} \\
& =\frac{7 \pi}{6} \text { radians }
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 2

The radius of a circle is 8 cm . Find
(i) the angle at the centre of the circle subtended by an arc of length 10 cm
(ii) the length of the arc if the angle subtended at the centre of the circle is $\frac{\pi}{4}$.
(i) Length of $\operatorname{arc} l=r \theta \Rightarrow \theta=\frac{l}{r}=\frac{10}{8} \Rightarrow \theta=\frac{5}{4}$ radians.
(ii) Length of $\operatorname{arc}=r \theta$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =8 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \\
& =2 \pi \mathrm{~cm}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Section 3.2 Trigonometric ratios

In your study of trigonometry so far you will have used the theorem of Pythagoras and trigonometric ratios to find the missing sides or angles of a right-angled triangle.
The three basic trigonometric ratios are given below:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin A=\frac{\text { opposite side }}{\text { hypotenuse }} \\
& \cos A=\frac{\text { adjacent side }}{\text { hypotenuse }} \\
& \tan A=\frac{\text { opposite side }}{\text { adjacent side }}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 1

If $\tan B=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{2}$, find the value of $\sin B$ and $\cos B$.
$\tan B=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{2} \Rightarrow$ opposite side to $B$ is $\sqrt{5}$ and adjacent side is 2 .
Now draw a rough sketch of a right-angled triangle.
Let $x$ be the length of the hypotenuse.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{2}=2^{2}+(\sqrt{5})^{2} \ldots(\sqrt{5})^{2}=5 \\
& x^{2}=4+5 \\
& x^{2}=9 \Rightarrow x=3
\end{aligned}
$$

From the triangle: $\sin B=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{3} \quad$ and $\quad \cos B=\frac{2}{3}$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-104.jpg?height=300&width=327&top_left_y=463&top_left_x=1152)

## Parts of a degree

A degree can be divided into 60 parts.

$$
1^{\circ}=60^{\prime}
$$

Each part is called 1 minute, written $1^{\prime}$.
Thus $34.5^{\circ}=34^{\circ} 30^{\prime}$.
To find $\tan 34.5^{\circ}$ or $34^{\circ} 30^{\prime}$ on your calculator, you may use either of these methods:

1. For $\tan 34.5^{\circ}$
key in $\tan 34.5=$
Result $=0.6873$
2. For $\tan 34^{\circ} 30^{\prime}$
key in tan $3 4 \longdiv { \circ },,, 30 \quad \circ \quad \circ$
Result $=0.6873$

## Using the $\sin ^{-1} \cos ^{-1}$ and $\tan ^{-1}$ keys

If we are given that $\sin A=0.8661$, we can find the angle $A$ by using the $\sin ^{-1} \mathrm{key}$.
The $\sin ^{-1}$ key is got by keying in SHIFT sin.
Thus if $\sin A=0.8661$, we find $A$ by keying in SHIFT sin $0.8661=$.
The result is $60.008^{\circ}=60^{\circ}$.
Similarly, if $\tan B=1.2734$, we find the angle $B$ by keying in SHIFT $\tan 1.2734=$.
The result is $51.86^{\circ} \ldots$ correct to 2 decimal places.

## The angles $\mathbf{3 0}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}, \mathbf{4 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$ and $\mathbf{6 0}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$

The angles $30^{\circ}, 45^{\circ}$ and $60^{\circ}$ are used very frequently and we will use triangles to express the sine, cosine and tangent ratios of these angles as fractions or surds.
The triangle on the right is isosceles where the equal sides are 1 unit in length.
The hypotenuse is $\sqrt{2}$ units in length.
The sine, cosine and tangent ratios can be read from the triangle.

$$
\sin 45^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \quad \cos 45^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \quad \tan 45^{\circ}=1
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-105.jpg?height=357&width=350&top_left_y=1399&top_left_x=1284)

The given right-angled triangle has angles of $60^{\circ}$ and $30^{\circ}$.
We can use this triangle to write down the trigonometric ratios of these two angles.

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\sin 60^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} & \cos 60^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2} & \tan 60^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} \\
\sin 30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2} & \cos 30^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} & \tan 30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}
\end{array}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-105.jpg?height=352&width=274&top_left_y=1823&top_left_x=1360)

Note: The sine, cosine and tangent ratios for $30^{\circ}, 45^{\circ}$ and $60^{\circ}$ are given on page 13 of Formulae and Tables.

## Section 3.3 Trigonometric functions

In this section we will deal with angles from $0^{\circ}$ to $360^{\circ}$ and show how to find the sine, cosine or tangent of these angles.
Angles are measured from the positive $x$-axis.
Positive angles are measured in an anti-clockwise direction.
Negative angles are measured in a clockwise direction.
The diagrams below illustrate two positive and two negative angles.

## 1. The Unit Circle

The circle on the right has centre at $(0,0)$ and radius 1 unit in length. It is generally referred to as the unit circle.
Let $\mathrm{P}(x, y)$ be any point on the circle, as shown.
From the triangle OPC,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x}{1}=\cos \theta & & x=\frac{y}{1}=\sin \theta \\
\Rightarrow \quad & x=\cos \theta & & \Rightarrow y=\sin \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad$ the coordinates of P are $(\boldsymbol{\operatorname { c o s }} \boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\operatorname { s i n }} \boldsymbol{\theta})$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-107.jpg?height=343&width=386&top_left_y=1073&top_left_x=1132)

The coordinates of any point on the unit circle are $(\boldsymbol{\operatorname { c o s }} \boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\operatorname { s i n }} \boldsymbol{\theta})$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-107.jpg?height=343&width=499&top_left_y=1460&top_left_x=1132)

## 2. The Four Quadrants

The $x$-axis and $y$-axis divide a full rotation of $360^{\circ}$ into 4 quadrants, as shown on the right.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-107.jpg?height=411&width=470&top_left_y=1848&top_left_x=755)

The unit circle on the right shows an angle, $\theta$, in each of the four quadrants. The signs shown in each triangle determine whether a ratio is positive or negative.

The positive ratios in the four quadrants are shown in the highlighted section below.
(i) In the 1st quadrant, all (A) positive
(ii) In the 2nd quadrant, $\sin (\mathrm{S})$ only positive
(iii) In the 3rd quadrant,
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-108.jpg?height=229&width=232&top_left_y=555&top_left_x=742) tan(T) only positive
(iv) In the 4 th quadrant, $\cos (\mathrm{C})$ only positive

The reference angle, of any angle A , is always the smallest (acute) angle to the horizontal $x$-axis.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-108.jpg?height=963&width=606&top_left_y=173&top_left_x=1026)

## Example 1

Find in surd form
(i) $\sin 120^{\circ}$
(ii) $\cos 225^{\circ}$
(i) $\sin 120^{\circ}$ :
$120^{\circ}$ is in the second quadrant
$\Rightarrow$ the sine ratio is positive
The reference angle is $180^{\circ}-120^{\circ}=60^{\circ}$.
Using page 13 of Formulae and Tables,
$\sin 60^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \Rightarrow \sin 120^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-108.jpg?height=343&width=350&top_left_y=1370&top_left_x=1133)
(ii) $\cos 225^{\circ}$ :
$225^{\circ}$ is in the third quadrant
$\Rightarrow$ the cosine ratio is negative
The reference angle is $225^{\circ}-180^{\circ}=45^{\circ}$.
$\cos 45^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \Rightarrow \cos 225^{\circ}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-108.jpg?height=343&width=362&top_left_y=1738&top_left_x=1120)

## Example 2

(i) Express in surd form, $\cos \left(-135^{\circ}\right)$.
(ii) If $\sin x=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$, find two values for $x$ if $0^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 360^{\circ}$.
(i) $\cos \left(-135^{\circ}\right)=\cos 45^{\circ}$ in the 3rd quadrant

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\cos 45^{\circ} \ldots \text { cosine negative in 3rd quadrant } \\
& =-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-109.jpg?height=402&width=402&top_left_y=386&top_left_x=1176)
(ii) $\sin x=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$
$\Rightarrow x=60^{\circ}$ in the 3 rd or 4th quadrants
$\Rightarrow x=\left(180^{\circ}+60^{\circ}\right)$ or $x=\left(360^{\circ}-60^{\circ}\right)$
$\Rightarrow x=240^{\circ}$ or $x=300^{\circ}$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-109.jpg?height=394&width=399&top_left_y=812&top_left_x=1177)

The diagram on the right shows an acute angle $\theta$ in each of the four quadrants.
CAST shows the positive ratios in these quadrants.
The diagram shows that $\sin \left(180^{\circ}+\theta\right)=-\sin \theta$ as the sine is negative in the 3rd quadrant.
The results for sine, cosine and tangent are given below:
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-109.jpg?height=336&width=685&top_left_y=1265&top_left_x=947)

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\sin \left(180^{\circ}-\theta\right)=\sin \theta & \cos \left(180^{\circ}-\theta\right)=-\cos \theta & \tan \left(180^{\circ}-\theta\right)=-\tan \theta \\
\sin \left(180^{\circ}+\theta\right)=-\sin \theta & \cos \left(180^{\circ}+\theta\right)=-\cos \theta & \tan \left(180^{\circ}+\theta\right)=\tan \theta \\
\sin \left(360^{\circ}-\theta\right)=-\sin \theta & \cos \left(360^{\circ}-\theta\right)=\cos \theta & \tan \left(360^{\circ}-\theta\right)=-\tan \theta
\end{array}
$$

## Section 3.4 Sine Rule - Area of a triangle

In this section dealing with the sides and angles of any triangle, we will use the usual notation $A, B$ and $C$ to denote the angles and $a, b$ and $c$ to denote the sides opposite these angles.
In your study of trigonometry so far, you will have used the Theorem of Pythagoras to find sides and angles of a right-
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-111.jpg?height=243&width=463&top_left_y=251&top_left_x=1169) angled triangle.
In order to deal with any triangle, we will establish the first of two very important relationships between the angles and sides of the triangle.
This rule is known as the sine rule.

## 1. The Sine Rule: $\frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}=\frac{c}{\sin C}$

## To prove the Sine rule $\frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}$

## Mandatory Proof

Proof (i) Acute angled triangle
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-111.jpg?height=309&width=360&top_left_y=977&top_left_x=388)
i) $\frac{h}{b}=\sin A \quad \Rightarrow \quad h=b \sin A$
ii) $\frac{h}{a}=\sin B \quad \Rightarrow \quad h=a \sin B$
$\therefore a \sin B=b \sin A$
(ii) Obtuse angled triangle
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-111.jpg?height=305&width=501&top_left_y=974&top_left_x=1011)
i) $\frac{h}{b}=\sin A \quad \Rightarrow \quad h=b \sin A$
ii) $\frac{h}{a}=\sin \left(180^{\circ}-B\right) \Rightarrow h=a \sin \left(180^{\circ}-B\right)$

$$
\Rightarrow h=a \sin B
$$

$\therefore a \sin B=b \sin A$
(since $\left(180^{\circ}-B\right)$ is in the $2^{\text {nd }}$ quadrant with reference angle $B$ and sine is $(+)^{\text {ve }}$ in the $2^{\text {nd }}$ quadrant)

In both cases if we divide by $\sin A \sin B$ we get

$$
\frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}
$$

Similarly it may be shown that $\frac{\boldsymbol{b}}{\boldsymbol{\operatorname { s i n }} \boldsymbol{B}}=\frac{\boldsymbol{c}}{\boldsymbol{\operatorname { s i n }} \boldsymbol{C}}$

$$
\therefore \frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}=\frac{c}{\sin C}
$$

## Sine Rule $\quad \frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}=\frac{c}{\sin C}$ or $\frac{\sin A}{a}=\frac{\sin B}{b}=\frac{\sin C}{c}$

Note: If we need to find an unknown angle using the sine rule, then $\frac{\sin A}{a}=\frac{\sin B}{b}$ is a more suitable form of the rule.

To use the sine rule to solve a triangle, we need to know one side and the angle opposite this side as well as one other angle or side.

## Example 1

In the triangle $\mathrm{ABC},|\mathrm{AB}|=8 \mathrm{~cm},|\angle \mathrm{BAC}|=30^{\circ}$ and $|\angle \mathrm{BCA}|=40^{\circ}$. Find $|\mathrm{BC}|$.

A sketch of the triangle is shown opposite.
Always draw a diagram of the triangle and add the information given.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-112.jpg?height=300&width=590&top_left_y=557&top_left_x=952)

From the triangle, $|\mathrm{AB}|=8, \mathrm{~A}=30^{\circ}$ and $\mathrm{C}=40^{\circ}$.

$$
\begin{array}{lr} 
& \frac{a}{\sin 30^{\circ}}=\frac{8}{\sin 40^{\circ}} \\
\Rightarrow & a \sin 40^{\circ}=8 \sin 30^{\circ} \\
\Rightarrow & a=\frac{8 \sin 30^{\circ}}{\sin 40^{\circ}} \\
\Rightarrow & a=6.22 \mathrm{~cm} \\
\Rightarrow & |\mathrm{BC}|=6.22 \mathrm{~cm}
\end{array}
$$

In the triangle ABC

## 2. The area of a triangle

In the given triangle, $h$ is the perpendicular distance from A to $[\mathrm{BC}]$.
Area of $\triangle \mathrm{ABC}=\frac{1}{2}$ base $\times$ perpendicular height

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{1}{2} a \times h \\
& =\frac{1}{2} a h
\end{aligned}
$$

But $\frac{h}{c}=\sin \mathrm{B} \quad \Rightarrow \quad h=c \sin \mathrm{~B}$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-113.jpg?height=329&width=420&top_left_y=1849&top_left_x=1214)
$\Rightarrow \quad$ area of $\triangle \mathrm{ABC}=\frac{1}{2} a c \sin \mathrm{~B}$

By using different perpendicular heights, area of $\triangle \mathrm{ABC}=\frac{1}{2} a b \sin \mathrm{C} \quad$ or $\quad \frac{1}{2} a c \sin \mathrm{~B} \quad$ or $\quad \frac{1}{2} b c \sin \mathrm{~A}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Area of } \triangle \mathrm{ABC}= & \frac{1}{2} a b \sin \mathrm{C} \text { or } \frac{1}{2} a c \sin \mathrm{~B} \text { or } \frac{1}{2} b c \sin \mathrm{~A} \\
\text { In words, area }= & \text { half the product of any two sides multiplied } \\
& \text { by the sine of the angle between them. }
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 4

If the area of the given triangle is $12 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$, find the measure of the acute angle $A$, correct to the nearest degree.

Area of $\triangle=\frac{1}{2}(6)(7) \sin A$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{2}(6)(7) \sin A & =12 \\
\Rightarrow \quad \sin A & =\frac{12}{21}=0.5714 \\
\Rightarrow \quad A & =\sin ^{-1}(0.5714) \\
\Rightarrow \quad A & =34.8^{\circ}=35^{\circ}, \text { to the nearest degree }
\end{aligned}
$$

## Section 3.5 The Cosine rule

In the given triangle, we are given the lengths of the three sides but no angle. We cannot use the sine rule here to find the angle A .

Instead we use another rule for solving triangles.
It is called the cosine rule.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-117.jpg?height=253&width=439&top_left_y=557&top_left_x=1190)

The cosine rule states that for any triangle,

$$
a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c \cos \mathrm{~A} .
$$

## The Cosine Rule: $\quad a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c \cos \mathrm{~A}$

To prove the Cosine Rule $\boldsymbol{a}^{\mathbf{2}}=\boldsymbol{b}^{\mathbf{2}}+\boldsymbol{c}^{\mathbf{2}}-\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{b} \boldsymbol{c} \cos \mathbf{A}$
Draw triangle with vertex $A$ at the origin, $B(c, 0)$ and point C making an obtuse angle with A .
Draw a circle of radius length $b$ with centre at A .
Since the coordinates of any point on a unit circle

## Mandatory Proof

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-117.jpg?height=211&width=354&top_left_y=1073&top_left_x=1242) can be written as ( $\cos \theta, \sin \theta$ ), the coordinates of C can now be written as $C(b \cos A, b \sin A)$. $|B C|=a$ and $|B C|$ is the distance from ( $c, 0$ ) to ( $b \cos A, b \sin A$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow a^{2} & =(c-b \cos A)^{2}+(0-b \sin A)^{2} \\
\Rightarrow a^{2} & =c^{2}-2 b c \cos A+b^{2} \cos ^{2} A+b^{2} \sin ^{2} A \\
& =c^{2}-2 b c \cos A+b^{2}\left(\cos ^{2} A+\sin ^{2} A\right) \\
& =c^{2}-2 b c \cos A+b^{2} \quad\left(\cos ^{2} A+\sin ^{2} A=1\right) \\
\Rightarrow a^{2} & =b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c \cos A
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-117.jpg?height=310&width=407&top_left_y=1316&top_left_x=1192)

Similarly it may be proved that
$b^{2}=a^{2}+c^{2}-2 a c \cos B$ and $c^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}-2 a b \cos C$.

The cosine rule is generally used:
(i) to find the third side of a triangle when the other two sides and the included angle are given
(ii) to solve a triangle when the lengths of the three sides are given.

$$
a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c \cos A
$$

or
$\cos A=\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}}{2 b c}$

$$
b^{2}=a^{2}+c^{2}-2 a c \cos B
$$

or

$$
\cos B=\frac{a^{2}+c^{2}-b^{2}}{2 a c}
$$

$$
c^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}-2 a b \cos C
$$

or

$$
\cos C=\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}}{2 a b}
$$

## Example 1

In the triangle $\mathrm{ABC},|\mathrm{AB}|=8,|\mathrm{AC}|=10$ and $|\angle \mathrm{BAC}|=50^{\circ}$.
Find $|\mathrm{CB}|$.
Let $|\mathrm{CB}|=a$.
Using

$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{2} & =b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c \cos \mathrm{~A} \\
a^{2} & =10^{2}+8^{2}-2(10)(8) \cos 50^{\circ} \\
& =100+64-160(0.6428) \\
a^{2} & =61.15 \\
a & =\sqrt{61.15}=7.8, \text { correct to one decimal place } \\
|\mathrm{CB}| & =7.8
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 2

In the given triangle $\mathrm{PQR},|\mathrm{PR}|=7 \mathrm{~cm},|\mathrm{PQ}|=6.8 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $|\mathrm{RQ}|=9 \mathrm{~cm}$.
Find $|\angle \mathrm{RPQ}|$.
We require the angle P , so we start with $\cos \mathrm{P}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos \mathrm{P} & =\frac{q^{2}+r^{2}-p^{2}}{2 q r} \\
& =\frac{7^{2}+(6.8)^{2}-9^{2}}{2(7)(6.8)} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \cos \mathrm{P} & =0.1495 \\
\Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{P} & =\cos ^{-1}(0.1495) \\
\Rightarrow \quad|\angle \mathrm{RPQ}| & =81.4^{\circ}
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-118.jpg?height=305&width=468&top_left_y=852&top_left_x=1124)

## Section 3.6 Problems in three dimensions

In this section you will deal with trigonometric problems in three dimensions.
One of the first things you are required to do is to identify which angles or which lengths you need to calculate. For this reason it is of the utmost importance that you sketch good diagrams.

Most problems in three dimensions consist of a series of connected triangles. It is important to identify right-angled triangles in particular. If we require an angle or length in a particular triangle, it simplifies the work if the triangle is drawn separately. From this point on you can work from a two-dimensional figure, just as you have been doing so far in this chapter.

In this cube there are many connected right-angled triangles.

## Example 3

From the top of a vertical cliff 100 m high, a boat A lies in a direction $\mathrm{S} 30^{\circ} \mathrm{E}$ and a boat B lies due east.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-124.jpg?height=385&width=607&top_left_y=359&top_left_x=635)

The angle of elevation of the top of the cliff from boat A is $20^{\circ}$ and the angle of elevation from boat B is $15^{\circ}$. Calculate how far the boats are apart.
Give your answer correct to the nearest metre.
(i) Using $\triangle \mathrm{ADC}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& & \frac{100}{|\mathrm{CA}|} & =\tan 20^{\circ} \\
\Rightarrow & & |\mathrm{CA}| \tan 20^{\circ} & =100 \\
\Rightarrow & & |\mathrm{CA}| & =\frac{100}{\tan 20^{\circ}}=\frac{100}{0.364} \\
\Rightarrow & & |\mathrm{CA}| & =274.7 \mathrm{~m}
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) Using $\triangle \mathrm{BCD}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{100}{|\mathrm{CB}|}=\tan 15^{\circ} \\
\Rightarrow & |\mathrm{CB}|=\frac{100}{\tan 15^{\circ}} \\
\Rightarrow & |\mathrm{CB}|=373.2 \mathrm{~m}
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-124.jpg?height=232&width=555&top_left_y=1273&top_left_x=993)
(iii) Using $\triangle \mathrm{ACB}$ :

Here we use the cosine rule to find $|\mathrm{AB}|$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |\mathrm{AB}|^{2}=(373.2)^{2}+(274.7)^{2} \\
& \quad \quad-2(373.2)(274.7) \cos 60^{\circ} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad|\mathrm{AB}|^{2}=112220.29 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad|\mathrm{AB}|=334.99 \\
& \quad=335 \text { metres }
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-124.jpg?height=348&width=487&top_left_y=1575&top_left_x=1058)
$\Rightarrow$ the boats are 335 metres apart.

## Section 3.7 Graphs of trigonometric functions

## Graph of $y=\sin x$

Consider a point A on a unit circle.
The $y$-coordinate of this point is the length of the opposite side of a right-angled triangle.

The sine ratio (at this point) is
$\sin x=\frac{\text { Opposite }}{\text { Hypotenuse }}=\frac{\text { Opposite }}{1}$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-128.jpg?height=432&width=640&top_left_y=1835&top_left_x=991)

As the point moves around the circle, the angle increases from 0 to $2 \pi$ radians $\left(0^{\circ}\right.$ to $\left.360^{\circ}\right)$.
At the same time the $y$-coordinate of A changes from 0 to 1 to 0 to -1 to 0 .
By measuring the length of the opposite $(y)$ and the angle $(x)$ contained, a set of ordered pairs ( $x, y$ ) is created. When plotted these points all lie on a smooth curve, $y=\sin x$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-129.jpg?height=284&width=1420&top_left_y=424&top_left_x=209)

It is also clear that the point can continue to rotate making larger angles but the $y$-value continues to repeat within a range of values $[-1,1]$.

This function, $y=\sin x$, is therefore said to be periodic.
The shortest measurement along the $x$-axis after which it repeats is the period of the function.
The period of $y=\sin x$ is $360^{\circ}$ or $2 \pi$ radians.
The period of a function, $f$, is a positive number $\boldsymbol{a}$ such that $f(x+a)=f(x)$.
The period of $\sin (x)$ is $2 \pi$ as $\sin (x+2 \pi)=\sin (x)$.

## Graph of $\boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{\operatorname { c o s }} \boldsymbol{x}$

The cosine function, $\cos x=\frac{\text { Adjacent }}{\text { Hypotenuse }}=\frac{\text { Adjacent }}{1}$, is also a periodic function.

When the angle $x=0^{\circ}$, the Adjacent side $=1$
As $x$ increases to $90^{\circ}$, the Adjacent side decreases to 0 .
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-129.jpg?height=428&width=496&top_left_y=1309&top_left_x=1133)

As $x$ increases further (past $90^{\circ}$ ), the adjacent side becomes negative and decreases in value to -1 .

The cosine graph repeats after $2 \pi$.

The period of $\cos x$ is $2 \pi$ radians and its range is $[-1,1]$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-129.jpg?height=369&width=899&top_left_y=1756&top_left_x=729)

## Graph of $\boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{\operatorname { t a n }} \boldsymbol{x}$

Since $\tan x=\frac{\text { opposite }}{\text { adjacent }}$, at $x=0$, the opposite is zero
$\therefore \tan 0=0$.
As the angle $x$ increases the opposite side increases as the adjacent decreases.
At $x=\frac{\pi}{4}$, the opposite and adjacent sides have the same length $\therefore \tan \frac{\pi}{4}=1$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-130.jpg?height=489&width=802&top_left_y=161&top_left_x=825)

However as $x$ approaches $90^{\circ}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right.$ radians $)$, the opposite approaches 1 while the adjacent approaches zero and so $\tan \frac{\pi}{2}=\frac{\text { opposite }}{\text { adjacent }}$, is undefined.
We cannot get a value for $\tan x$ when $x= \pm 90^{\circ}, \pm 270^{\circ}, \ldots$
Note: $\tan \left(89^{\circ}\right) \approx \frac{1}{0.02} \approx 57.3$ (try to imagine the position of the point $\left(89^{\circ}, 57.3\right)$ on the $y=\tan x$ graph above)

The curve gets closer and closer to the $x=\frac{\pi}{2}$ line but never touches it.
The lines $x=\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3 \pi}{2}, \frac{5 \pi}{2} \ldots$ and $x=\frac{-\pi}{2}, \frac{-3 \pi}{2}, \frac{-5 \pi}{2} \ldots$ are asymptotes to the curve.
As can be seen from the graph, $\tan x$ has a period of $\pi$ radians $\left(180^{\circ}\right)$.
Its range is R , the set of real numbers.

| Function | Domain | Range | Period |
| :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| $y=\sin x$ | $\mathbb{R}$ | $[-1,1]$ | $360^{\circ}(2 \pi$ radians $)$ |
| $y=\cos x$ | $\mathbb{R}$ | $[-1,1]$ | $360^{\circ}(2 \pi$ radians $)$ |
| $y=\tan x$ | $\mathbb{R} \backslash\left\{ \pm 90^{\circ}, \pm 270^{\circ}, \ldots\right\}$ | $\mathbb{R}$ | $180^{\circ}(\pi$ radians $)$ |

## Section 3.8 Related trigonometric graphs

The main features of trigonometric graphs are:
(a) Range: the interval on the $y$-axis from the lowest to the highest value.
(b) Midline: a horizontal line which lies halfway between the highest and lowest points.
(c) Amplitude: the distance between the midline and the maximum or minimum values of the graph.
(d) Period: the shortest distance along the $x$-axis after which the graph repeats itself.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-132.jpg?height=565&width=588&top_left_y=1455&top_left_x=1040)

## 1. Changes to the amplitude, $y=b \sin x$

For $y=2 \sin x$ every value of $\sin x$ is multiplied by 2 , the graph stretches in the $y$ direction by a factor of 2 . The amplitude is now 2.

The amplitude of $y=b \sin x$ is $|\boldsymbol{b}|$.
The period does not change, however, the range changes from $[-1,1]$ to $[-2,2]$.

The range of $y=\sin x$ is $[-1,1]$
The range of $y=b \sin x$ is $[-|b|,|b|]$
Similarly $y=b \cos x$ has an amplitude of $|b|$ and a range
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-133.jpg?height=576&width=437&top_left_y=172&top_left_x=1191) of $[-|b|,|b|]$

If $b=-1$ then the graphs, $y=-\sin x$ and $y=-\cos x$ are reflections in the $x$-axis of $y=\sin x$ and $y=\cos x$ repectively.
(Note; the amplitude remains $|-1|=1$ )
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-133.jpg?height=546&width=544&top_left_y=972&top_left_x=256)
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-133.jpg?height=546&width=545&top_left_y=972&top_left_x=859)
2. Changes to the period $y=\sin (c x)$

| $\boldsymbol{x}$ | $0^{\circ}$ | $45^{\circ}$ | $90^{\circ}$ | $135^{\circ}$ | $180^{\circ}$ | $225^{\circ}$ | $270^{\circ}$ | $315^{\circ}$ | $360^{\circ}$ |
| :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: |
| $\boldsymbol{2} \boldsymbol{x}$ | $0^{\circ}$ | $90^{\circ}$ | $180^{\circ}$ | $270^{\circ}$ | $360^{\circ}$ | $450^{\circ}$ | $540^{\circ}$ | $630^{\circ}$ | $720^{\circ}$ |
| $\boldsymbol{\operatorname { s i n }} \mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}$ | 0 | 1 | 0 | -1 | 0 | 1 | 0 | -1 | 0 |

The graph of $y=\sin 2 x$ has the same overall shape as $y=\sin x$ but the period has decreased to $180^{\circ}$ ( $\pi$ radians).
In other words two sine curves fit into the domain $0^{\circ}$ to $360^{\circ}$.
$\therefore$ for $\sin 2 x$, the period is $\frac{360^{\circ}}{2}=180^{\circ}$
In general for $y=\sin n x, \boldsymbol{n}$ sine waves fit into the domain $0^{\circ}$ to $360^{\circ}$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-133.jpg?height=367&width=546&top_left_y=1825&top_left_x=1085)
$\therefore y=\sin n x$ has a period of $\frac{360^{\circ}}{n}=\frac{2 \pi}{n}$.

$$
\text { e.g., } \begin{aligned}
y & =\sin 3 x \text { has a period of } \frac{2 \pi}{3} \\
y & =\sin \frac{x}{4} \text { has a period of } \frac{2 \pi}{\frac{1}{4}}=8 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly $y=\cos n x$ has a period of $\frac{2 \pi}{n}$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-134.jpg?height=296&width=1291&top_left_y=399&top_left_x=222)
3. Graphs of the form, $y=a+b \sin (c x)$ and $y=a+b \cos (c x)$

The graph of $y=1+\cos x$ is obtained from the graph of $y=\cos x$ by a translation of 1 unit in the positive direction of the $y$-axis.

Adding 1 unit to $y=\cos x$ does not change the period or the amplitude of the function.

Adding 1 unit does change the maximum and minimum values of the function and so changes the range.

It therefore changes the mid-line as well.
The mid-line of $y=1+\cos x$ is $y=1$
The range of $y=\cos x$ is $[-1,1]$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-134.jpg?height=597&width=599&top_left_y=805&top_left_x=1030)

The range of $y=1+\cos x$ is $[0,2]$
The range of $y=-1+\cos x$ is $[-2,0]$

In general for graphs of the form, $y=a+b \sin (c x)$ and $y=a+b \cos (c x)$
(i) $y=a$ is the the mid-line
(ii) the amplitude is $|b|$
(iii) $y=a+|b|$ is the maximum value of the curve $y=a-|b|$ is the minimum value of the curve
(iv) The range is $[a-|b|, a+|b|]$
(v) The period is $\left(\frac{2 \pi}{c}\right)$ radians or $\left(\frac{360^{\circ}}{c}\right)$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-134.jpg?height=494&width=564&top_left_y=1592&top_left_x=1029)

## Section 3.9 General solutions of trigonometric equations

In Section 3.3 we solved equations such as $\sin x=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ for angles in the range $0 \leqslant x \leqslant 360^{\circ}$ (or $0 \leqslant x \leqslant 2 \pi$ ).
This generally gave us two values for the angle $x$.
Consider again the equation $\cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}$.
A calculator in degree mode gives an answer of $60^{\circ}$.
But recall that this is only the principal value.
Check that $\theta=300^{\circ}$ and $\theta=420^{\circ}$ also work.
The equation $\cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}$ has no restriction on the set of values of $\theta$ that are solutions.

The graph below shows the function $y=\cos \theta$ and the function $y=\frac{1}{2}$.
The graph shows that there is an infinite number of solutions to the equation $\cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}$ as the graph of $y=\cos \theta$ repeats itself indefinitely.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-140.jpg?height=324&width=1119&top_left_y=324&top_left_x=360)

In the range $0^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^{\circ}$, there are two values of $\theta$ for which $\cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}$.
These value are $60^{\circ}$ and $300^{\circ}$.
Notice that the value $\theta=420^{\circ}$ is $60^{\circ}+360^{\circ}$ and $\theta=660^{\circ}$ is $300^{\circ}+360^{\circ}$.
Thus further solutions of the equation are found by repeatedly adding $360^{\circ}$ to the angles $60^{\circ}$ and $300^{\circ}$.

So the solutions to the equation $\cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}$ are

$$
\theta=60^{\circ}+n 360^{\circ} \text { or } \theta=300^{\circ}+n 360^{\circ}, \text { where } n \text { is an integer. }
$$

This is called the general solution of the equation.
We can find the general solution of any trigonometric equation in the form $\sin \theta=k$ or $\cos \theta=k$ in the same way.
This method is given below.

Remember
To find the general solution of $\sin x=k$ or $\cos x=k$, you find the two solutions in the interval $0^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^{\circ}$ and then add $n 360^{\circ}$ to each of the solutions.

## Example 1

Find the general solution of the equation $\cos \theta=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}, \theta$ in radians.
$\cos \theta=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \theta=\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)=\frac{\pi}{6}\left(30^{\circ}\right) \ldots$ the reference angle cosine is negative in the 2 nd and 3rd quadrants.
$\cos \theta=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \Rightarrow \theta=\frac{\pi}{6}$ in the 2nd and 3rd

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \theta=\frac{5 \pi}{6} \quad \text { or } \quad \frac{7 \pi}{6}
$$

The general solution is $2 n \pi+\frac{5 \pi}{6}$ or $2 n \pi+\frac{7 \pi}{6}, n \in Z$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-140.jpg?height=515&width=517&top_left_y=1699&top_left_x=1043)

## Example 2

Solve the equation $\sin 3 \theta=\frac{1}{2}$, for $\theta \in \mathbf{R}, \theta$ in radians.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sin 3 \theta=\frac{1}{2} & \Rightarrow 3 \theta=\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{\pi}{6} \\
& \Rightarrow 3 \theta=\frac{\pi}{6} \text { or } \frac{5 \pi}{6} \ldots \text { sine is positive in the } 1 \text { st and } 2 \text { nd quadrants }
\end{aligned}
$$

All the solutions for $3 \theta$ (i.e. the general solution) are

The full general solution should be found for $3 \theta$ before dividing by 3 to find the general values for $\theta$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
3 \theta & =2 n \pi+\frac{\pi}{6} \quad \text { or } \quad 2 n \pi+\frac{5 \pi}{6} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \theta & =\frac{2 n \pi}{3}+\frac{\pi}{18} \quad \text { or } \quad \frac{2 n \pi}{3}+\frac{5 \pi}{18}, n \in Z
\end{aligned}
$$

Note: The following example illustrates how we use the general solution of an equation to find all the solutions in a given interval.

## Example 3

Find all the solutions for $\cos 2 \theta=-\frac{1}{2}$ for $0^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^{\circ}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos 2 \theta=-\frac{1}{2} & \Rightarrow 2 \theta=\cos ^{-1}\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right) \\
& \Rightarrow 2 \theta=60^{\circ} \ldots \text { the reference angle }
\end{aligned}
$$

cosine is negative in the 2 nd and 3rd quadrants.

$$
\Rightarrow 2 \theta=120^{\circ} \text { or } 240^{\circ}
$$

To find all the solutions we add $n\left(360^{\circ}\right)$ to each angle.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 \theta=120^{\circ}+n\left(360^{\circ}\right) \text { or } 2 \theta=240^{\circ}+n\left(360^{\circ}\right) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \theta=60^{\circ}+n\left(180^{\circ}\right) \text { or } \theta=120^{\circ}+n\left(180^{\circ}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-141.jpg?height=315&width=312&top_left_y=1290&top_left_x=1228)

To find the values of $\theta$ in the range $0^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^{\circ}$, we let $n=0,1,2,3, \ldots$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n=0 \Rightarrow \theta=60^{\circ} \text { or } 120^{\circ} \\
& n=1 \Rightarrow \theta=240^{\circ} \text { or } 300^{\circ} \\
& n=2 \Rightarrow \theta=420^{\circ} \text { or } 480^{\circ}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $420^{\circ}$ and $480^{\circ}$ are outside the range $0^{\circ}$ to $360^{\circ}$, we disregard these values.
Thus the values of $\theta$ are $60^{\circ}, 120^{\circ}, 240^{\circ}, 300^{\circ}$.

## Section 4.1 Revision of formulae

In this section we will deal with some coordinate geometry formulae that you will have met in the course of your work for the Junior Certificate. The main formulae dealing with coordinates are given below:

1. Distance between two points

The distance between $\mathrm{A}\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ and $\mathrm{B}\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$ is $|\mathrm{AB}|=\sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}}$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-150.jpg?height=364&width=628&top_left_y=1027&top_left_x=1006)
2. The midpoint of a line segment

The midpoint M of the line segment joining $\mathrm{A}\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ and $\mathrm{B}\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$ is

$$
\left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}, \quad \frac{y_{1}+y_{2}}{2}\right)
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-150.jpg?height=343&width=527&top_left_y=1427&top_left_x=1024)

## 3. The slope of a line

In the diagram on the right, the slope, $m$, of AB is found by getting the value of

$$
\frac{\text { vertical change }}{\text { horizontal change }}=\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}
$$

The slope, $m$, of the line passing through ( $x_{1}, y_{1}$ ) and ( $x_{2}, y_{2}$ ) is

$$
m=\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-150.jpg?height=371&width=625&top_left_y=1880&top_left_x=1003)

## 4. Positive and negative slopes

As we go from left to right, the slope is positive if the line is rising and the slope is negative if the line is falling.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-151.jpg?height=324&width=559&top_left_y=324&top_left_x=640)

The slope of a horizontal line is zero.

## 5. Parallel lines

The lines $a$ and $b$ in the given diagram both have the slope $\frac{3}{2}$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-151.jpg?height=555&width=605&top_left_y=882&top_left_x=617)

These lines are parallel.

## 6. Perpendicular lines

The given lines $a$ and $b$ are perpendicular.
The slope of $a$ is $\frac{3}{2}$.
The slope of $b=-\frac{2}{3}$.
Notice that one slope is the reciprocal of the other with the sign changed.

Notice also that the product of the two slopes is -1 , i.e.,

$$
-\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{3}{2}=-1
$$

If two lines are perpendicular, the product of their slopes is -1 , i.e.,

$$
m_{1} \times m_{2}=-1
$$

Parallel lines have equal slopes.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-151.jpg?height=552&width=505&top_left_y=1624&top_left_x=1124)

## Example 1

$\mathrm{A}(3,1), \mathrm{B}(2,-3)$ and $\mathrm{C}(-1, k)$ are three points in the plane.
If $\mathrm{AB} \perp \mathrm{AC}$, find the value of $k$.
$\mathrm{A}(3,1)$ and $\mathrm{B}(2,-3)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{A}(3,1) \text { and } \mathrm{C}(-1, k) \\
& \text { Slope of } \mathrm{AC}=\frac{k-1}{-1-3} \\
&=\frac{k-1}{-4}
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\mathrm{AB} \perp \mathrm{AC}$, then the product of the slopes equals -1 .

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad 4 \times \frac{k-1}{-4}=-1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{4(k-1)}{-4}=-1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{4(k-1)}{4}=1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad k-1=1 \\
& \quad \Rightarrow \quad k=2
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Slope of } \mathrm{AB} & =\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}} \\
& =\frac{-3-1}{2-3} \\
& =\frac{-4}{-1}=4
\end{aligned}
$$

lopes equals -1

## Section 4.2 The area of a triangle

The area of the triangle with vertices $(0,0)$, ( $x_{1}, y_{1}$ ) and ( $x_{2}, y_{2}$ ) is

$$
\text { Area }=\frac{1}{2}\left|x_{1} y_{2}-x_{2} y_{1}\right|
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-154.jpg?height=324&width=456&top_left_y=253&top_left_x=918)

## Example 1

Find the area of the triangle with vertices $(0,0),(-2,1)$ and $(3,4)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Area } & =\frac{1}{2}\left|x_{1} y_{2}-x_{2} y_{1}\right| \\
& =\frac{1}{2}|(-2)(4)-(3)(1)| \\
& =\frac{1}{2}|-8-3| \\
& =\frac{1}{2}|-11| \\
& =5 \frac{1}{2} \text { square units }
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right) & \left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right) \\
\downarrow & \downarrow \\
(-2,1) & (3,4)
\end{array}
$$

The modulus symbol || indicates that we take the positive value of the answer.

Note: If none of the vertices of the triangle is at the origin, we find the image of the triangle under a translation so that one of the vertices is $(0,0)$.

Let $\quad(2,4) \rightarrow(0,0)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (7,3) \rightarrow(5,-1) \\
& (4,1) \rightarrow(2,-3)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we take 2 from each $x$-value and 4 from each $y$-value for each of the points.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-154.jpg?height=538&width=489&top_left_y=1249&top_left_x=1146)

## Example 2

Find the area of the triangle with vertices $(1,5),(-3,1)$ and $(3,-5)$.
Let

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (1,5) \rightarrow(0,0) \\
& (-3,1) \rightarrow(-4,-4) \\
& (3,-5) \rightarrow(2,-10)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we take 1 from each $x$-value and 5 from each $y$-value.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Area of triangle } & =\frac{1}{2}\left|x_{1} y_{2}-x_{2} y_{1}\right| \\
& =\frac{1}{2}|(-4)(-10)-(2)(-4)| \\
& =\frac{1}{2}|40+8| \\
& =\frac{1}{2}|48| \\
& =24 \text { square units }
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-155.jpg?height=135&width=298&top_left_y=234&top_left_x=1122)

Note: To find the area of a quadrilateral, divide it into two triangles.

## Section 4.3 The equation of a line

The equation of a line is generally given in the form $\boldsymbol{a} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{b} \boldsymbol{y}+\boldsymbol{c}=\mathbf{0}$, e.g., $2 x+3 y-12=0$.
This may be described as the general form of the equation of a line.
To find the equation of a line, we generally need to know
(i) a point on the line
(ii) the slope of the line.

If $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ is a point on the line and $m$ is the slope, we then use $\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{y}_{1}=\boldsymbol{m}\left(\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}_{1}\right)$ to find the equation of the line.

## The equation $\boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{m} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{c}$

If the equation of a line is in the form

$$
y=m x+c, \text { then }
$$

(i) the slope is $m$
(ii) the line intersects the $y$-axis at $(0, c)$.
$c$ is the value of $y$ at the point where the line crosses the $y$-axis and is called the $y$ intercept.

The equation of a line with slope $m$ and containing the point ( $x_{1}, y_{1}$ ) is

$$
y-y_{1}=m\left(x-x_{1}\right)
$$

The equation $\boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{m} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{c}$ is generally referred to as the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line.

If the equation of a line is in the form $2 x+3 y-7=0$, we express it in the form $y=m x+c$. The slope is $m$.

For example, if $\quad 3 x-4 y+3=0$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
-4 y & =-3 x-3 \\
\Rightarrow \quad 4 y & =3 x+3 \Rightarrow y=\frac{3}{4} x+\frac{3}{4} \Rightarrow m=\frac{3}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note: The slope of a line is defined as the tangent of the angle which the line makes with the positive direction of the $x$-axis.

1. If the angle is less than $90^{\circ}$, the slope is positive.
2. If the angle is between $90^{\circ}$ and $180^{\circ}$, the slope is negative.
3. $\tan 45^{\circ}=1 ; \tan 135^{\circ}=-1$

## Example 1

Find the equation of the line through the point $(-2,3)$ which is perpendicular to the line $2 x-y+5=0$.

To find the slope of $2 x-y+5=0$, we express it in the form $y=m x+c$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 x-y+5=0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad & -y=-2 x-5 \\
\Rightarrow \quad & y=2 x+5 \ldots \quad \text { multiply each term by }-1 \\
\Rightarrow \quad & \text { the slope is } 2 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The slope of the line perpendicular to this line is $-\frac{1}{2}$.
Equation of line through $(-2,3)$ with slope $-\frac{1}{2}$ is:

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
y-y_{1} & =m\left(x-x_{1}\right) & \left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right) & =(-2,3) \\
y-3 & =-\frac{1}{2}(x+2) & m & =-\frac{1}{2} \\
y-3 & =\frac{-x}{2}-1 & \\
\Rightarrow & 2 y-6 & =-x-2 \ldots & \text { multiply each term by } 2 \\
\Rightarrow & x+2 y & -4=0 \text { is the required equation. }
\end{array}
$$

## More difficult problems

To find the equation of a line (or lines) we generally require two pieces of information.
From the information given it may not be possible to find a point on the line and the slope of the line immediately. When dealing with more difficult problems, the following approaches should prove useful.

1. The equation of any line through the point $(3,4)$, for example, is $y-4=m(x-3)$, i.e. $m x-y-3 m+4=0$.

A second condition should enable us to find the value or values of $m$.
2. The equation of any line parallel to $\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{3} \boldsymbol{y}+8=0$ is $\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{3} \boldsymbol{y}+\boldsymbol{c}=0$.

The equation of any line perpendicular to $2 x-3 y+8=0$ is $3 x+2 y+k=0$.
The equation of any line parallel to $a x+b y+c=0$ is $a x+b y+k=0$.
The equation of any line perpendicular to $a x+b y+c=0$ is $b x-a y+k=0$.

## To find where a line intersects the axes

To find the point of intersection of a line and
(i) the $x$-axis, let $y=0$ and find the $x$-value
(ii) the $y$-axis, let $x=0$ and find the $y$-value.

## Example 2

Find the value of $k$ if the lines $2 x+k y+5=0$ and $(k+6) x+2 y-9=0$ are perpendicular to each other.
$2 x+k y+5=0 \Rightarrow$ the slope $m_{1}=\frac{-2}{k}$
$(k+6) x+2 y-9=0 \Rightarrow$ the slope $m_{2}=\frac{-(k+6)}{2}$
Since the lines are perpendicular, $m_{1} \times m_{2}=-1$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & & \frac{-(k+6)}{2}\left(\frac{-2}{k}\right) & =-1 \\
\Rightarrow & & \frac{2(k+6)}{2 k} & =-1 \\
\Rightarrow & & k+6 & =-k \\
\Rightarrow & & 2 k & =-6 \\
\Rightarrow & & k & =-3
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 3

Find the equations of the line $l$ through the point $(4,2)$ so that the area of the triangle formed by $l$ and the positive $x$ and $y$-axes is 25 square units.

Equation of any line through $(4,2)$ is

$$
y-2=m(x-4)
$$

i.e. $m x-y+2-4 m=0$
$l$ intersects the $x$-axis at $y=0$
$y=0 \Rightarrow x=\frac{4 m-2}{m}$
$x=0 \Rightarrow y=2-4 m$
Area of shaded $\triangle=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{4 m-2}{m}\right)(2-4 m)$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-158.jpg?height=461&width=527&top_left_y=1377&top_left_x=1024)

Area $=25 \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{4 m-2}{m}\right)(2-4 m)=25$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow(4 m-2)(2-4 m) \quad=50 m \\
& \Rightarrow 8 m-16 m^{2}-4+8 m=50 m \\
& \Rightarrow 16 m^{2}+34 m+4 \quad=0 \\
& \Rightarrow(16 m+2)(m+2) \quad=0 \\
& \Rightarrow m=-\frac{1}{8} \text { or } m \quad=-2
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore$ the equations of the line $l$ are
(i) $y-2=-\frac{1}{8}(x-4) \quad$ or
(ii) $\begin{array}{ll} & y-2=-2(x-4) \\ & \Rightarrow y-2=-2 x+8 \\ & \Rightarrow 2 x+y-10=0\end{array}$
$\therefore$ the two equations are $x+8 y-20=0$ and $2 x+y-10=0$

Note: To verify that a point is on a given line, we substitute the coordinates of $x$ and $y$ into the equation of the line. If the coordinates satisfy the equation, then the point is on the line.

For example, the point $(-3,2) \in 2 x-4 y+14=0$, because

$$
\begin{aligned}
2(-3)-4(2)+14 & =-6-8+14 \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

## Section 4.4 Dividing a line segment in a given ratio

## Internal division

In the given diagram, the point C divides the line segment $[\mathrm{PQ}]$ in the ratio $a: b$. The coordinates of C are given by the formula,
$\mathrm{C}=\left(\frac{b x_{1}+a x_{2}}{b+a}, \frac{b y_{1}+a y_{2}}{b+a}\right)$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-161.jpg?height=385&width=541&top_left_y=1184&top_left_x=1092)

## Example 1

Find the coordinates of the point which divides the line segment $\mathrm{A}(-1,3)$ and $\mathrm{B}(4,-2)$ in the ratio $h: k=2: 1$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{A}(-1,3) \quad \mathrm{B}(4,-2) \quad h: k=2: 1 \\
& \left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right) \quad\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right) \\
& \text { Internal divisor }=\left(\frac{h x_{2}+k x_{1}}{h+k}, \frac{h y_{2}+k y_{1}}{h+k}\right) \\
& =\left(\frac{(2)(4)+(1)(-1)}{2+1}, \frac{(2)(-2)+(1)(3)}{2+1}\right) \\
& =\left(\frac{7}{3},-\frac{1}{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

## Section 4.5 Concurrencies of a triangle

The line which joins a vertex of a triangle to the midpoint of the opposite side is called a median.

In the given triangle [AM] is the median.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-162.jpg?height=301&width=536&top_left_y=1844&top_left_x=1095)

## 1. The Centroid

The given diagram shows the three medians $[\mathrm{AE}],[\mathrm{BF}]$ and $[\mathrm{CD}]$ intersecting at the point G .
G is called the centroid of the triangle.
The medians of a triangle divide each other in the ratio $2: 1$.

In the given triangle,
$|\mathrm{AG}|:|\mathrm{GE}|=2: 1 ; \quad|\mathrm{BG}|:|\mathrm{GF}|=2: 1$ and
$|\mathrm{CG}|:|\mathrm{GD}|=2: 1$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-163.jpg?height=394&width=555&top_left_y=232&top_left_x=1080)

If $\mathrm{A}\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right), \mathrm{B}\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$ and $\mathrm{C}\left(x_{3}, y_{3}\right)$ are the coordinates of the vertices of a triangle, then the coordinates of the centroid, G , are

$$
\mathrm{G}=\left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}}{3}, \frac{y_{1}+y_{2}+y_{3}}{3}\right)
$$

## 2. The circumcentre

The circumcentre of a triangle is the point of intersection of the mediators (the perpendicular bisectors of the sides) of a triangle.
The line segment from a vertex of a triangle to the circumcentre is the radius of the circumcircle.
This is shown here as $r$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-163.jpg?height=461&width=461&top_left_y=1000&top_left_x=1170)

## 3. The orthocentre

The orthocentre of a triangle is the point of intersection of the perpendiculars from the vertices to the opposite sides.
In the given triangle, H is the orthocentre.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-163.jpg?height=333&width=546&top_left_y=1550&top_left_x=1085)

## Example 1

The vertices of a triangle are $\mathrm{A}(-4,3), \mathrm{B}(0,-5)$ and $\mathrm{C}(3,4)$. Find the coordinates of
(i) the centroid
(ii) the orthocentre of the triangle.
(i) Centroid $=\left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}}{3}, \frac{y_{1}+y_{2}+y_{3}}{3}\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left(\frac{-4+3+0}{3}, \frac{3+4+(-5)}{3}\right) \\
& =\left(-\frac{1}{3}, \frac{2}{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) The orthocentre is the point of intersection of the perpendiculars from the vertices to the opposite sides, as shown.
(Two perpendiculars are sufficient.)
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-164.jpg?height=574&width=567&top_left_y=227&top_left_x=1032)

$$
\text { Slope of } \mathrm{BC}=\frac{4+5}{3-0}=\frac{9}{3}=3
$$

$\Rightarrow$ slope of $\mathrm{AE}=-\frac{1}{3}$
Equation of AE: $y-y_{1}=m\left(x-x_{1}\right) \quad\left(x, y_{1}\right)=(-4,3)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
y-3 & =-\frac{1}{3}(x+4) \\
\Rightarrow \quad 3 y-9 & =-x-4 \\
\Rightarrow \quad x+3 y-5 & =0 \ldots 1
\end{aligned}
$$

Slope of AC: $\frac{4-3}{3+4}=\frac{1}{7}$
$\Rightarrow \quad$ slope of $\mathrm{BD}=-7$
Equation of $\mathrm{BD}: \quad y+5=-7(x-0) \quad \mathrm{B}=(0,-5)$

$$
\Rightarrow 7 x+y+5=0 \ldots \text { (2) }
$$

Solving equations (1) and (2): $x+3 y=5 \ldots$ (1)

$$
\begin{equation*}
7 x+y=-5 . \tag{2}
\end{equation*}
$$

(1) $\quad x+3 y=5$
(2) $\times 3: \quad 21 x+3 y=-15$
$\therefore$ the coordinates of the orthocentre are $(-1,2)$

## Section 4.6 Perpendicular distance from a point to a line

The perpendicular distance, $d$, from the point $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ to the line $a x+b y+c=0$ is given by the formula

$$
d=\frac{\left|a x_{1}+b y_{1}+c\right|}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-165.jpg?height=312&width=395&top_left_y=792&top_left_x=1066)

## Example 1

(i) Find the perpendicular distance from the point $(1,-4)$ to the line $3 x-y-2=0$.
(ii) Find the distance between the parallel lines $3 x-4 y+12=0$ and $3 x-4 y-1=0$.
(i) Perpendicular distance $=\frac{\left|a x_{1}+b y_{1}+c\right|}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}} \ldots\left\{\begin{array}{c}a x+b y+c=3 x-y-2 \\ \left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)=(1,-4)\end{array}\right\}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{|3(1)+(-1)(-4)+(-2)|}{\sqrt{3^{2}+1^{2}}} \\
& =\frac{5}{\sqrt{10}}=\frac{5 \sqrt{10}}{10}=\frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) To find the distance between two parallel lines, we find a point on one of the lines and then find the distance from that point to the other line.
A point on the line $3 x-4 y+12=0$ is $(0,3)$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-165.jpg?height=184&width=386&top_left_y=1747&top_left_x=1158)

Perpendicular distance from $(0,3)$ to $3 x-4 y-1=0$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
d=\frac{|3(0)+(-4)(3)-1|}{\sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}}} & =\frac{|-12-1|}{\sqrt{25}} \\
& =\frac{|-13|}{5}=\frac{13}{5}=2 \frac{3}{5}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Points in relation to a given line

The sign of the expression inside the modulus signs can be very useful when we are investigating whether points are on the same side or opposite sides of a given line.

1. Perpendiculars to a line from points on the same side of the line have the same sign.
2. Perpendiculars from points on opposite sides of a line have different signs.

## Example 2

Investigate whether the points $(5,-2)$ and $(3,-3)$ lie on the same side of the line $5 x-4 y-30=0$.

The perpendicular distance from $(5,-2)$ to the line $5 x-4 y-30=0$ is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Distance } & =\frac{a x_{1}+b y_{1}+c}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}} \\
& =\frac{5(5)+(-4)(-2)-30}{\sqrt{5^{2}+4^{2}}} \\
& =\frac{25+8-30}{\sqrt{41}}=\frac{3}{\sqrt{41}} \ldots \text { positive }
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we do not use the modulus bars || as we require a positive or negative answer.

The perpendicular distance from $(3,-3)$ to the line $5 x-4 y-30=0$ is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Distance } & =\frac{5(3)+(-4)(-3)-30}{\sqrt{5^{2}+4^{2}}} \\
& =\frac{15+12-30}{\sqrt{41}}=\frac{-3}{\sqrt{41}} \ldots \text { negative }
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the perpendicular distances are opposite in sign, the points are on opposite sides of the line.

## Example 3

Find the equations of the two lines which are parallel to the line $3 x-4 y-1=0$ and 3 units from it.

The equation of any line parallel to $3 x-4 y-1=0$ has the form $3 x-4 y+k=0$. $\left(0,-\frac{1}{4}\right)$ is a point on the line $3 x-4 y-1=0$.
The distance from $\left(0,-\frac{1}{4}\right)$ to $3 x-4 y+k=0$ is 3 units.

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow \frac{\left|3(0)-4\left(-\frac{1}{4}\right)+k\right|}{\sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}}}=3 & \\
\Rightarrow \frac{|1+k|}{5}=3 & |x|=3 \\
\Rightarrow \frac{1+k}{5}= \pm 3 & \Rightarrow x= \pm 3 \\
& \Rightarrow k=14 \text { or } k=-16
\end{array}
$$

The equations of the lines are

$$
3 x-4 y+14=0 \quad \text { or } \quad 3 x-4 y-16=0
$$

## Section 4.7 The angle between two lines

The diagram shows two lines $l_{1}$ and $l_{2}$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-169.jpg?height=388&width=517&top_left_y=306&top_left_x=661)

Let the slope of $l_{1}$ be $m_{1}$.

$$
\Rightarrow m_{1}=\tan \alpha
$$

Let the slope of $l_{2}$ be $m_{2}$.

$$
\Rightarrow m_{2}=\tan \beta
$$

The angle, $\theta$, between the lines is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta & =\alpha-\beta \\
\tan \theta & =\tan (\alpha-\beta) \\
& =\frac{\tan \alpha-\tan \beta}{1+\tan \alpha \tan \beta} \\
\Rightarrow \tan \theta & =\frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The second angle between $l_{1}$ and and $l_{2}$ is $\left(180^{\circ}-\theta\right)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tan \left(180^{\circ}-\theta\right) & =-\tan \theta \\
& =-\frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the angle between $l$, and $l_{2}$ may be acute or obtuse, we generally define the angle as shown on the right.

$$
\tan \theta= \pm \frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}}
$$

Note: In practice we generally use $\tan \theta=\left|\frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}}\right|$ to find the acute angle, $\theta$, between two lines.

The obtuse angle is obtained by finding $180^{\circ}-\theta$.

## Example 1

Find the acute angle between the lines $y=2 x+5$ and $3 x+y=7$.
Let the slope of $y=2 x+5$ be $m_{1} \Rightarrow m_{1}=2$
Let the slope of $3 x+y=7$ be $m_{2} \Rightarrow m_{2}=-3$
Let $\theta$ be the angle between the lines.

$$
\tan \theta=\left|\frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}}\right|=\left|\frac{2-(-3)}{1+2(-3)}\right|=\left|\frac{2+3}{1-6}\right|=\left|\frac{5}{-5}\right|=|-1|=1
$$

$\tan \theta=1 \Rightarrow \theta=45^{\circ}$ is the acute angle.
Note: the obtuse angle is $180^{\circ}-45^{\circ}=135^{\circ}$.

## More difficult problems

A particular type of problem in coordinate geometry involves finding the equations of two lines through a given point and which make angles of $45^{\circ}$, for example, with a given line.

From the given diagram we can see that there are 2 lines through P which make angles of $45^{\circ}$ with the line $l$.

To find the equations of the required lines, we start with the formula
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-170.jpg?height=350&width=401&top_left_y=193&top_left_x=1228)

$$
\tan \theta= \pm \frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}}
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle between the line required and the given line and $m_{1}$ is the slope of the given line.

By solving the equation using the $\pm$ signs, we get two values for $m_{2}$.

## Example 2

Find the equations of the two lines through the point $(2,3)$ which make angles of $45^{\circ}$ with the line $x-2 y=1$.

Let $m_{1}$ be the slope of the given line $x-2 y=1$.

$$
\Rightarrow m_{1}=\frac{1}{2}
$$

Let $m_{2}$ be the slope of the required line.
The angle between the two lines is $45^{\circ}$.
Using the formula $\tan \theta= \pm \frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \tan 45^{\circ}= \pm \frac{m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}} \\
& \Rightarrow 1= \pm \frac{\frac{1}{2}-m_{2}}{1+\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) m_{2}} \Rightarrow c \\
& \Rightarrow 2+m_{2}=1-2 m_{2}
\end{aligned} \quad \begin{aligned}
& \text { or } \\
\Rightarrow & 2+m_{2}=-\left(1-2 m_{2}\right) \\
\Rightarrow 3 m_{2}=-1 & \text { or }
\end{aligned} \quad \begin{array}{ll}
2+m_{2}=-1+2 m_{2} \\
\Rightarrow m_{2}=-\frac{1}{3} & \Rightarrow m_{2}=3
\end{array}
$$

Taking these two values of the slope and the point $(2,3)$ we get these equations

$$
\begin{array}{rlrlrl}
\boldsymbol{m}_{2}=-\frac{1}{3}: & y-y_{1} & =m\left(x-x_{1}\right) & \boldsymbol{m}_{2}=\mathbf{3}: & y-y_{1} & =m\left(x-x_{1}\right) \\
y-3 & =-\frac{1}{3}(x-2) & & y-3 & =3(x-2) \\
3 y-9 & =-x+2 & \text { i.e } & & 3 x-y-3 & =0 \\
\text { i.e. } x+3 y-11 & =0 & & &
\end{array}
$$

$\therefore x+3 y-11=0$ and $3 x-y-3=0$ are the required lines.

## Section 4.8 Using linear relationships to solve problems

In this section we will illustrate the importance of the straight line when the relationship between two variables is plotted on a graph. In many scientific experiments when the relationship between two sets of data is displayed graphically, the points often lie on, or very close to, a straight line.

This line is generally referred to as the line of best fit.
We will deal more fully with this line in another part of our course.
In this section we will deal only with straight-line graphs and show how useful they can be in the world of science and business.

## Example 1

A spring has an unstretched length of 10 cm . When it is hung with a load of 80 g attached, the stretch length is 28 cm . Assuming that the extension of the spring is proportional to the load,
(i) draw a graph of extension E against load L .
(Put load L on the horizontal axis.)
(ii) find the equation of the line you have drawn in terms of L and E .
(iii) use your graph to find the load required to extend the spring to a length of 20 cm .

This particular spring passes its elastic limit when it is stretched to four times its original length. (This means that if it is stretched more than that it will not return to its original length.)
(iv) Find the load which would cause this to happen.
(i) Two points on the line are $(0,10)$ and $(80,28)$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-172.jpg?height=626&width=940&top_left_y=1172&top_left_x=447)
(ii) The line contains the points $(0,10)$ and $(80,28)$

Slope $=\frac{28-10}{80-0}=\frac{18}{80}=\frac{9}{40}$
Equation of line: $y-y_{1}=m\left(x-x_{1}\right) \quad$ Here L replaces $x$ and E replaces $y$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{E}-10 & =\frac{9}{40}(\mathrm{~L}-0) \\
\Rightarrow \quad 40 \mathrm{E}-400 & =9 \mathrm{~L} \\
\Rightarrow \quad 9 \mathrm{~L}-40 \mathrm{E}+400 & =0 \text { is the required equation }
\end{aligned}
$$

(iii) From the graph it can be seen that a load of 44 grams is required to extend the spring to a length of 20 cm .
(iv) A load of 133 grams is required for the elastic limit of 40 cm to be reached.
