## Section 11.3 Finding the equation of a circle

To find the equation of a circle we generally require,
(i) the centre and (ii) the radius of the circle.

In the more difficult questions these two pieces of information are not given directly. We have to rely, therefore, on our knowledge of the geometry of the circle to find the centre and the radius.

Three geometrical properties of the circle are particularly important.

1. The perpendicular from the centre of a circle to a chord bisects the chord
In the given figure, $\mathrm{CM} \perp \mathrm{AB}$

$$
|\mathrm{AM}|=|\mathrm{MB}|
$$

The corollary to this theorem is property 2, given below.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-432.jpg?height=310&width=314&top_left_y=175&top_left_x=1229)
2. The perpendicular bisector of a chord contains the centre

In the given diagram, $l$ is the perpendicular bisector of the chord $[\mathrm{AB}]$ and $m$ is the perpendicular bisector of the chord [BC].

Each of these bisectors contains the centre, O.
The point of intersection of these two perpendicular bisectors is the centre of the circle.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-432.jpg?height=390&width=359&top_left_y=559&top_left_x=1209)

Note: This property is very useful when we require the equation of a circle containing three given points.
3. The perpendicular to a tangent at the point of contact passes through the centre of the circle
In the given diagram the tangent, $t$, touches the circle at the point P .

The perpendicular to $t$ through P contains the centre O .
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-432.jpg?height=338&width=390&top_left_y=1118&top_left_x=1229)

## 1. Equation of circle containing three given points

## Example 1

Find the equation of the circle which contains the points $\mathrm{A}(2,1), \mathrm{B}(0,5)$ and $C(-1,2)$.

The given diagram shows the circle containing the three given points.
$l$ is the perpendicular bisector of [CA]
$m$ is the perpendicular bisector of [BC].
We now find the equations of $l$ and $m$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-432.jpg?height=336&width=477&top_left_y=1718&top_left_x=1065)

Equation of $l$ :
Slope of $\mathrm{AC}=\frac{1-2}{2+1}=-\frac{1}{3}$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \text { slope of } l=3
$$

Midpoint of $[\mathrm{AC}]=\left(\frac{2-1}{2}, \frac{1+2}{2}\right)$

$$
=\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{2}\right)
$$

Equation of $l$ : point $=\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{2}\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& & \text { slope } & =3 \\
& & y-\frac{3}{2} & =3\left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & & y-\frac{3}{2} & =3 x-\frac{3}{2} \\
\Rightarrow & & 2 y-3 & =6 x-3 \\
\Rightarrow & & 6 x-2 y & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & 3 x-y & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

Equation of $m$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Slope of } \mathrm{BC} & =\frac{5-2}{0+1}=\frac{3}{1}=3 \\
\Rightarrow \quad \text { slope of } m & =-\frac{1}{3} \\
\text { Midpoint of }[\mathrm{BC}] & =\left(\frac{0-1}{2}, \frac{5+2}{2}\right) \\
& =\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{7}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Equation of $m$ : point $=\left(-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{7}{2}\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { slope }=-\frac{1}{3} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad y-\frac{7}{2}=-\frac{1}{3}\left(x+\frac{1}{2}\right) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad y-\frac{7}{2}=-\frac{x}{3}-\frac{1}{6} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 6 y-21=-2 x-1 \\
& \Rightarrow 2 x+6 y-20=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x+3 y-10=0 \ldots \text { (2) }
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving the equations for $l$ and $m$ we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { (1): } \quad 3 x-y=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad 3 x-y=0 \\
& \text { (2): } \quad x+3 y=10 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \frac{3 x+9 y=30}{-10 y=-30 \quad \Rightarrow \quad y=3}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
y=3 \Rightarrow x=1
$$

$\therefore$ the centre of the circle is $\mathrm{O}(1,3)$.
Radius of the circle is $|\mathrm{OA}|$.

$$
|\mathrm{OA}|=\sqrt{(1-2)^{2}+(3-1)^{2}}=\sqrt{1+4}=\sqrt{5}
$$

Equation of circle with centre $(1,3)$ and radius $\sqrt{5}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (x-1)^{2}+(y-3)^{2}=(\sqrt{5})^{2} \\
\Rightarrow \quad(x-1)^{2}+(y-3)^{2} & =5 \text { is the required equation }
\end{aligned}
$$

## Alternative method

The equation of a circle containing three points can also be found by using the general equation of the circle, $x^{2}+y^{2}+2 g x+2 f y+c=0$. By substituting the three sets of values for $x$ and $y$ we will then have 3 simultaneous equations.
This is illustrated in the following example.

## Example 2

Find the equation of the circle which contains the points $(0,0),(3,1)$ and $(3,9)$.
Let the equation of the circle be $x^{2}+y^{2}+2 g x+2 f y+c=0$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
(0,0) \in \text { the circle } & \Rightarrow 0+0+0+0+c=0 \Rightarrow c=0 \ldots \text { (1) } \\
(3,1) \in \text { the circle } & \Rightarrow 9+1+6 g+2 f+c=0 \\
& \Rightarrow 6 g+2 f=-10 \ldots \text { (2) } \ldots(c=0) \\
(3,9) \in \text { the circle } & \Rightarrow 9+81+6 g+18 f+c=0 \\
& \Rightarrow 6 g+18 f=-90 \ldots \text { (3) } \ldots(c=0)
\end{aligned}
$$

We now solve equations (2) and (3).

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { (2): } 6 g+2 f=-10 \\
& \text { (3): } \frac{6 g+18 f=-90}{-16 f=80} \\
& \Rightarrow 16 f=-80 \Rightarrow f=-5 \\
& \therefore 6 g+2(-5)=-10 \\
& 6 g=0 \Rightarrow g=0 \\
& \therefore g=0, f=-5 \text { and } c=0
\end{aligned}
$$

We now substitute these values in the equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{2}+y^{2}+2 g x+2 f y+c=0 \Rightarrow x^{2}+y^{2}-10 y=0 \text { is the required } \\
& \text { equation }
\end{aligned}
$$

Note: If one of the three points on a circle is $(0,0)$, the method of finding the equation shown in Example 2 may be easier than the method shown in Example 1.

## 2. Equation of circle when given the equation of a tangent, the point of contact and one other point

## Example 3

Find the equation of the circle which touches the line $3 x-4 y-3=0$ at the point $\mathrm{A}(5,3)$ and which passes through the point $\mathrm{B}(-2,4)$.
A rough sketch of the circle is shown on the right.
The centre O lies on the perpendicular bisector of $[\mathrm{AB}]$.
The centre also lies on the line through $\mathrm{A}(5,3)$, perpendicular to the tangent
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-434.jpg?height=475&width=664&top_left_y=1625&top_left_x=927) $3 x-4 y-3=0$.
The centre, O , is the point of intersection of these two lines.
(i) Equation of the perpendicular bisector of $[\mathrm{AB}]$ :

Slope of $\mathrm{AB}=\frac{3-4}{5+2}=-\frac{1}{7}$
$\Rightarrow \quad$ Slope of perpendicular to $\mathrm{AB}=7$
Midpoint of $[\mathrm{AB}]=\left(\frac{-2+5}{2}, \frac{4+3}{2}\right)=\left(\frac{3}{2}, \frac{7}{2}\right)$
Equation of perpendicular bisector of $[\mathrm{AB}]$ :

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\text { point } & =\left(\frac{3}{2}, \frac{7}{2}\right) ; \quad \text { slope }=7 & \\
y-\frac{7}{2} & =7\left(x-\frac{3}{2}\right) & & \\
\Rightarrow \quad y-\frac{7}{2} & =7 x-\frac{21}{2} & & \\
\Rightarrow \quad & 2 y-7 & =14 x-21 & \Rightarrow \quad 14 x-2 y-14=0 \\
& & \Rightarrow \quad 7 x-y-7=0 \ldots
\end{array}
$$

(ii) Equation of line through A perpendicular to $3 x-4 y-3=0$ :

Slope of $3 x-4 y-3=0$ is $\frac{3}{4} \Rightarrow$ slope of perpendicular line $=-\frac{4}{3}$.
Equation of line: $\quad y-3=-\frac{4}{3}(x-5)$

$$
\begin{array}{lrl}
\Rightarrow & & 3 y-9=-4 x+20 \\
\Rightarrow & & 4 x+3 y-29=0 \ldots \text { (2) }
\end{array}
$$

Solving equations (1) and (2) we get:
(1) $\times 3: \quad 21 x-3 y=21$
(2) : $\frac{4 x+3 y=29}{25 x=50} \Rightarrow x=2$ and $y=7$
$\Rightarrow \quad(2,7)$ is the centre of the circle
The radius of the circle is the distance from $(2,7)$ to $(-2,4)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad \text { the radius } & =\sqrt{(-2-2)^{2}+(4-7)^{2}} \\
& =\sqrt{16+9}=\sqrt{25}=5
\end{aligned}
$$

The equation of the circle with centre ( 2,7 ) and radius $=5$ is

$$
(x-2)^{2}+(y-7)^{2}=25
$$

3. Equation of circle through two given points with its centre on a given line
The given diagram shows a circle $k$ containing two points A and B and a line $l$ which contains the centre of $k$.

The centre of the circle is found by getting the point of intersection of $l$ and the perpendicular bisector of $[\mathrm{AB}]$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-435.jpg?height=409&width=569&top_left_y=1856&top_left_x=1012)

## Example 4

Find the equation of the circle whose centre is on the line $l$ : $3 x-y-7=0$ and which passes through the points $\mathrm{A}(1,1)$ and $\mathrm{B}(2,-1)$.
$m$ is the perpendicular bisector of $[\mathrm{AB}]$. The centre of the circle is the point of intersection of $m$ and the line $3 x-y-7=0$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-436.jpg?height=486&width=633&top_left_y=384&top_left_x=909)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Midpoint of }[\mathrm{AB}] & =\left(\frac{3}{2}, 0\right) \\
\text { Slope of } \mathrm{AB} & =\frac{-1-1}{2-1} \\
& =-2
\end{aligned}
$$

Slope of $m=\frac{1}{2}$
Equation of $m$ : point $=\left(\frac{3}{2}, 0\right)$ and slope $=\frac{1}{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y-y_{1}=m\left(x-x_{1}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & y-0=\frac{1}{2}\left(x-\frac{3}{2}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & y=\frac{x}{2}-\frac{3}{4} \\
\Rightarrow & 4 y=2 x-3 \Rightarrow 2 x-4 y-3=0 . . . \text { equation of } m
\end{aligned}
$$

We now find the point of intersection of $\ell$ and $m$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& l: \quad 3 x-y=7 \quad(\times 2): \quad 6 x-2 y=14 \\
& m: \quad 2 x-4 y=3(\times 3): \quad \frac{6 x-12 y=9}{10 y=5} \Rightarrow y=\frac{1}{2} \\
& l: \quad 3 x-\frac{1}{2}=7 \\
& \quad \Rightarrow \quad 3 x=7 \frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow 3 x=\frac{15}{2} \Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2} \\
& \quad \therefore \quad \text { centre of circle, } C=\left(\frac{5}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The radius length is the distance from $\left(\frac{5}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right)$ to $(1,1)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \text { radius } & =\sqrt{\left(\frac{5}{2}-1\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{2}-1\right)^{2}} \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{9}{4}+\frac{1}{4}}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{4}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The equation of the circle is $(x-h)^{2}+(y-k)^{2}=r^{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow\left(x-\frac{5}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(y-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{10}{4} \\
& \Rightarrow\left(x-\frac{5}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(y-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{5}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note 1. The question in Example 4 may also be done by using the general equation $x^{2}+y^{2}+2 g x+2 f y+c=0$.
By substituting the points $(1,1)$ and $(2,-1)$ we get two equations in $g, f$ and $c$.
Since the line $3 x-y-7=0$ contains the centre ( $-g,-f$ ), we get the equation $-3 g+f-7=0$.
We then solve the three equations to get the values of $g, f$ and $c$.
2. A line is a tangent to a circle if it touches the circle at one point only.
Also, the perpendicular distance from the centre of a circle to a tangent is equal to the radius of the circle.

## 3. Showing that a line is a tangent to a circle

A line is a tangent to a circle if the perpendicular distance from the centre of the circle to the line
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-437.jpg?height=352&width=406&top_left_y=479&top_left_x=1228) is equal to the radius.

## Example 5

Show that the line $x+6 y-9=0$ is a tangent to the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}-4 x+10 y-8=0$.

The centre of the circle $=(2,-5)$ and radius $=\sqrt{(2)^{2}+(-5)^{2}+8}=\sqrt{37}$.
The perpendicular distance from $(2,-5)$ to the line $x+6 y-9=0$ is

$$
\frac{|2(1)+6(-5)-9|}{\sqrt{1^{2}+6^{2}}}=\frac{|2-30-9|}{\sqrt{37}}=\frac{|-37|}{\sqrt{37}}=\frac{37 \sqrt{37}}{37}=\sqrt{37}
$$

Since this perpendicular distance is equal to the radius,
$\Rightarrow$ the line is a tangent to the circle

## Section 11.4 Tangents to a circle

A line is a tangent to a circle if it intersects the circle at one and only one point.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-440.jpg?height=310&width=404&top_left_y=255&top_left_x=1194)

## 1. Finding the equation of the tangent to a circle at the point $P$ on the circle

In the given diagram, $t$ is a tangent to the circle at the point P and C is the centre of the circle.
CP is perpendicular to $t$.
To find the equation of $t$ :
(i) Find the slope of CP.
(ii) Write down the slope of $t$.
(iii) Find the equation of $t$ using
$y-y_{1}=m\left(x-x_{1}\right)$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-440.jpg?height=493&width=565&top_left_y=687&top_left_x=1066)

## Example 1

Find the equation of the tangent to the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}-4 x+2 y-20=0$ at the point $(5,-5)$ on the circle.

The centre of the circle is $\mathrm{C}(2,-1)$.
Slope of $\mathrm{CP}=\frac{-1+5}{2-5}=\frac{4}{-3}=-\frac{4}{3}$
$\Rightarrow$ slope of $t=\frac{3}{4}$
Equation of $t: \quad y+5=\frac{3}{4}(x-5)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad 4 y+20 & =3 x-15 \\
\Rightarrow \quad 3 x-4 y-35 & =0 \text { is the equation of the tangent }
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-440.jpg?height=437&width=581&top_left_y=1328&top_left_x=961)

## 2. Tangents to a circle parallel or perpendicular to a given line

Parallel and perpendicular lines.

1. Any line parallel to $a x+b y+c=0$ has equation $\quad a x+b y+k=0$
2. Any line perpendicular to $a x+b y+c=0$ has equation $b x-a y+k=0$

## Example 2

Find the equations of the two lines parallel to the line $3 x+4 y-6=0$ and which are tangents to the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}=25$.

A sketch of the line and circle are shown.
The two tangents parallel to $3 x+4 y-6=0$ are shown in red.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-441.jpg?height=475&width=645&top_left_y=272&top_left_x=946)

The equation of any line parallel to $3 x+4 y-6=0$ is $3 x+4 y+k=0$.
The radius of the circle is $\sqrt{25}=5$.
The perpendicular distance from the centre of the circle, $(0,0)$, to $3 x+4 y+k=0$ is equal to 5 .
$\Rightarrow \frac{|3(0)+4(0)+k|}{\sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}}}=5$
$\Rightarrow \frac{|k|}{5}=5$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { If }|x|=5 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x=5 \quad \text { or } \quad x=-5
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Rightarrow \frac{k}{5}=5 \quad$ or $\quad \frac{k}{5}=-5$
$\Rightarrow k=25$ or $k=-25$
The equations of the two tangents are

$$
3 x+4 y+25=0 \quad \text { or } \quad 3 x+4 y-25=0
$$

## 3. Tangents to a circle from a point $\mathbf{P}$ not on the circle

The diagram below illustrates that two tangents can be drawn to a circle from a point outside the circle, i.e. PA and PB are tangents to the circle $k$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-441.jpg?height=399&width=711&top_left_y=1703&top_left_x=564)

If we are asked to find the equations of the two tangents from the point $(2,3)$, for example, to a given circle, we first find in terms of the slope, $m$, the equation of any line through $(2,3)$.

This equation is $\quad y-3=m(x-2)$

$$
\text { i.e. } \quad m x-y+3-2 m=0 \text {. }
$$

We then find the perpendicular distance from the centre of the circle to this line and equate it to the radius to find the two values of $m$.

## Remember

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { The perpendicular distance from the } \\
& \text { point }\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right) \text { to the line } \\
& a x+b y+c=0 \text { is } \\
& \qquad d=\frac{\left|a x_{1}+b y_{1}+c\right|}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 3

Find the equations of the tangents to the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}=5$ from the point $(5,0)$.
The equation of any line through $(5,0)$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y-y_{1}=m\left(x-x_{1}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & y-0=m(x-5) \\
\Rightarrow & y=m(x-5) \\
\Rightarrow & m x-y-5 m=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Centre of circle $=(0,0)$
Radius of circle $=\sqrt{5}$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-442.jpg?height=434&width=678&top_left_y=957&top_left_x=863)

If the line $m x-y-5 m=0$ is a tangent to the circle, then the perpendicular distance from the centre of the circle, i.e. $(0,0)$, to the line is equal in length to the radius.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & \frac{|0 \cdot m+0(-1)-5 m|}{\sqrt{m^{2}+(-1)^{2}}}=\sqrt{5} \\
& =\frac{|-5 m|}{\sqrt{m^{2}+1}}=\sqrt{5} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{25 m^{2}}{m^{2}+1}=5 \\
\Rightarrow & 25 m^{2}=5\left(m^{2}+1\right) \\
\Rightarrow & 20 m^{2}=5 \\
\Rightarrow & m^{2}=\frac{1}{4} \Rightarrow m= \pm \frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The equations of the tangents are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& m=\frac{1}{2}: \quad y-0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 y=\frac{1}{2}(x-5) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x-2 y-5=0 \\
& m=-\frac{1}{2}: \quad y-0=-\frac{1}{2}(x-5) \\
& 2 y=-x+5 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x+2 y-5=0
\end{aligned}
$$

The equations of the two tangents are

$$
x-2 y-5=0 \quad \text { and } \quad x+2 y-5=0 .
$$

## 4. Length of a tangent to a circle from a given point

When dealing with problems involving tangents, it is important to remember that the line joining the centre of the circle to the point of tangency is perpendicular to the tangent.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-443.jpg?height=369&width=757&top_left_y=339&top_left_x=541)

We will use this information to find the length of a tangent to a circle from a given point.

This is illustrated in the following example.

To find the length of the tangent $[\mathrm{PT}]$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\mathrm{CP}|^{2} & =|\mathrm{PT}|^{2}+|\mathrm{CT}|^{2} \\
\Rightarrow \quad|\mathrm{PT}|^{2} & =|\mathrm{CP}|^{2}-|\mathrm{CT}|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 4

Find the length of the tangent from the point $(-5,8)$ to the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}-4 x-6 y+3=0$.

The centre of the circle is $(2,3)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { The radius } & =\sqrt{g^{2}+f^{2}-c} \\
& =\sqrt{4+9-3}=\sqrt{10} \\
\Rightarrow \quad|\mathrm{CT}| & =\sqrt{10} \\
|\mathrm{CP}| & =\sqrt{(2+5)^{2}+(3-8)^{2}} \\
& =\sqrt{49+25}=\sqrt{74}
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-443.jpg?height=409&width=501&top_left_y=1172&top_left_x=1041)

Since $\triangle \mathrm{CTP}$ is right-angled $\Rightarrow|\mathrm{PT}|^{2}=|\mathrm{CP}|^{2}-|\mathrm{CT}|^{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =74-10=64 \\
\Rightarrow \quad|\mathrm{PT}| & =\sqrt{64}=8
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore$ the length of the tangent is 8

## Section 11.5 Lines and circles: Common chord

## 1. Points of intersection of a line and a circle

We use simultaneous equations to find the point(s) of intersection of a line and a circle.
If there are two solutions, then the line intersects the circle at two points.
If there is only one point of intersection, the line is a tangent to the circle, as shown below.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-446.jpg?height=397&width=1003&top_left_y=794&top_left_x=420)

## Example 1

Find the points of intersection of the line $x+2 y-1=0$ and the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}+2 x+8 y-8=0$.

We start with the equation of the line and express $x$ in terms of $y$ or $y$ in terms of $x$. (Avoid fractions, if possible.)

$$
x+2 y-1=0 \Rightarrow x=-2 y+1
$$

We now substitute $(-2 y+1)$ for $x$ in the equation of the circle.

$$
\begin{array}{rlrlrl} 
& & (-2 y+1)^{2}+y^{2}+2(-2 y+1)+8 y-8 & =0 \\
& \Rightarrow & 4 y^{2}-4 y+1+y^{2}-4 y+2+8 y-8 & =0 \\
& \Rightarrow & 5 y^{2}-5=0 \Rightarrow & y^{2}-1 & =0 \\
& \Rightarrow & (y-1)(y+1) & =0 \\
& \Rightarrow & y=1 \text { or } y & =-1
\end{array}
$$

For each value for $y$, we find the corresponding $x$-value.

$$
y=1 \Rightarrow x=-1 ; \quad y=-1 \Rightarrow x=3
$$

The points of intersection are $(-1,1)$ and $(3,-1)$.

## Example 2

Find the point(s) of intersection of the line $2 x-y+8=0$ and the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}+4 x+2 y=0$ and hence show that the line is a tangent to the circle.

Line: $2 x-y+8=0 \Rightarrow y=2 x+8$
Circle:

$$
\text { le } \begin{aligned}
& & x^{2}+(2 x+8)^{2}+4 x+2(2 x+8) & =0 \\
& \Rightarrow & x^{2}+4 x^{2}+32 x+64+4 x+4 x+16 & =0 \\
& \Rightarrow & 5 x^{2}+40 x+80 & =0 \\
& \Rightarrow & x^{2}+8 x+16 & =0 \\
& \Rightarrow & (x+4)(x+4) & =0 \\
& \Rightarrow & x & =-4 \ldots \text { one value only }
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding $y$ value is: $2(-4)-y+8=0 \Rightarrow y=0$
The point of intersection is $(-4,0)$.
Since there is only one point of intersection, the line is a tangent to the circle.

## 2. Where a circle intersects the axes

A circle intersects the $x$-axis at the points where $y=0$.
A circle intersects the $y$-axis at the points where $x=0$.

## Example 3

Find the length of the intercept the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}-10 x+8 y+16=0$ makes on the $x$-axis.

The circle intersects the $x$-axis at the points where $y=0$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
y=0 & \Rightarrow x^{2}-10 x+16=0 \\
& \Rightarrow(x-8)(x-2)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow x=8 \text { or } x=2
\end{aligned}
$$

The circle intersects the $x$-axis at $(2,0)$ and $(8,0)$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-447.jpg?height=376&width=392&top_left_y=1406&top_left_x=1181)
$\therefore \quad$ the intercept on the $x$-axis is 6 .

## 3. The common chord or common tangent of two circles

Take the circles $s_{1}$ : $\quad x^{2}+y^{2}-4 x-2 y-4=0$
$\begin{aligned} \text { and } s_{2}: & x^{2}+y^{2}-6 x+4 y-3=0 \\ s_{1}-s_{2}: & 2 x-6 y-1=0\end{aligned}$

This is the equation of the line which passes through the points of intersection of the two circles.
(i) If the two circles intersect, then the line is the common chord of the two circles.
(ii) If the circles touch internally or externally, then the line is the common tangent.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-448.jpg?height=390&width=573&top_left_y=352&top_left_x=350)

Common chord
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-448.jpg?height=347&width=555&top_left_y=397&top_left_x=934)

Common tangent

The points of intersection of two circles may be found by following these steps:
(i) find the equation of the common chord
(ii) find the points of intersection of the chord and any one of the circles.

## Example 4

Find the equation of the common chord of the two circles $x^{2}+y^{2}-6 x+2 y+4=0$ and $x^{2}+y^{2}+2 x-4 y-6=0$.

The equation of the common chord is

The common chord of two circles $s_{1}=0$ and $s_{2}=0$ is $s_{1}-s_{2}=0$.

$$
\Rightarrow \quad-8 x+6 y+10=0
$$

$\Rightarrow 4 x-3 y-5=0$ is the required equation

Note: The points of intersection of the two circles in Example 4 above are found by solving the equations $4 x-3 y-5=0$ and $x^{2}+y^{2}-6 x+2 y+4=0$.

## Section 11.6 Touching circles - Chords and circles

## 1. Circles touching externally or internally

Two circles touch if they meet at one point only.
If two circles touch externally, then the distance between their centres is equal to the sum of their radii. In the given diagram $d$ is the distance between the two centres.
Since the circles touch externally,

$$
d=r_{1}+r_{2}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-450.jpg?height=364&width=560&top_left_y=313&top_left_x=1073)

If two circles touch internally, then the distance between their centres is equal to the difference of their radii.
In the given diagram,

$$
d=r_{1}-r_{2}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-450.jpg?height=362&width=367&top_left_y=729&top_left_x=1179)

## Example 1

Show that the circles $s_{1}: x^{2}+y^{2}-6 x-4 y+11=0$

$$
\text { and } s_{2}: x^{2}+y^{2}+4 x+6 y-19=0 \text { touch externally. }
$$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
s_{1}: & x^{2}+y^{2}-6 x-4 y+11=0 \Rightarrow \\
s_{2}: & x^{2}+y^{2}+4 x+6 y-19=0 \Rightarrow
\end{array} \quad \begin{aligned}
& \text { centre }=(3,2) \text { and } \\
& \text { radius }=\sqrt{3^{2}+2^{2}-11}=\sqrt{2} \\
&
\end{aligned} \quad \begin{aligned}
& \text { centre }=(-2,-3) \text { and } \\
& \text { radius }=\sqrt{(-2)^{2}+(-3)^{2}+19}=\sqrt{32}=4 \sqrt{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Distance between the centres $=\sqrt{(3+2)^{2}+(2+3)^{2}}=\sqrt{50}$

$$
=5 \sqrt{2}
$$

Sum of the two radii $=\sqrt{2}+4 \sqrt{2}=5 \sqrt{2}$
Since the distance between the centres $=$ the sum of the radii $=5 \sqrt{2}$, the circles touch externally.

## 2. Chords and circles

We have already encountered the very useful geometrical property of the circle which states that:

The perpendicular from the centre of a circle to a chord bisects the chord.

In the given diagram, $d$ is the length of the perpendicular from the centre, O , to the chord.

We use the Theorem of Pythagoras to find $d, r$ or $p$ as required.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-451.jpg?height=314&width=317&top_left_y=173&top_left_x=1315)

## Example 2

A circle $k$ has centre $\mathrm{C}(4,2)$ and makes a chord 6 units in length on the $y$-axis. Find the equation of $k$.

If the centre is $(4,2)$, then the length of the perpendicular $[\mathrm{BC}]$ is 4 units.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-451.jpg?height=486&width=551&top_left_y=766&top_left_x=658)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |\mathrm{AB}|=\frac{1}{2} \text { length of chord on } y \text {-axis } \\
\Rightarrow \quad & |\mathrm{AB}|=3 \\
& |\mathrm{AC}|^{2}=3^{2}+4^{2} \\
\Rightarrow \quad & |\mathrm{AC}|^{2}=25 \Rightarrow|\mathrm{AC}|=5 \Rightarrow \text { radius }=5
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad$ the circle has centre $(4,2)$ and radius 5
Equation of circle: $(x-4)^{2}+(y-2)^{2}=25$

## Section 11.7 Circles touching the $\boldsymbol{x}$-axis or $\boldsymbol{y}$-axis

If a circle touches the $x$-axis or $y$-axis, then the radius of the circle is equal to one of coordinates of its centre.

## 1. Circle touching the $\boldsymbol{x}$-axis

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-453.jpg?height=338&width=494&top_left_y=1495&top_left_x=319)

Radius $=|-f|$
$\Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{g^{2}+f^{2}-c}=|-f|$
$\Rightarrow \quad g^{2}+f^{2}-c=f^{2}$
$\Rightarrow \quad g^{2}-c=0$
$\Rightarrow \quad g^{2}=c$

## 2. Circle touching the $y$-axis

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-453.jpg?height=366&width=402&top_left_y=1465&top_left_x=1074)

Radius $=|-g|$
$\Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{g^{2}+f^{2}-c}=|-g|$
$\Rightarrow \quad g^{2}+f^{2}-c=g^{2}$
$\Rightarrow \quad f^{2}-c=0$
$\Rightarrow \quad f^{2}=c$

## Example 1

Find the equations of the two circles which contain the points $(3,-2)$ and $(2,-1)$ and which touch the $x$-axis.

Let the equation of the circle be

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+2 g x+2 f y+c=0 .
$$

$(2,-1) \in$ the circle

$$
\begin{align*}
\Rightarrow & & 4+1+2 g(2)+2 f(-1)+c & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & 4 g-2 f+c & =-5 \tag{1}
\end{align*}
$$

$(3,-2) \in$ the circle
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-454.jpg?height=406&width=491&top_left_y=358&top_left_x=1058)

$$
\begin{align*}
\Rightarrow & & 9+4+2 g(3)+2 f(-2)+c & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & 6 g-4 f+c & =-13 \ldots \tag{2}
\end{align*}
$$

If the circle touches the $x$-axis, the radius $=|-f|$

$$
\begin{align*}
\Rightarrow & & \sqrt{g^{2}+f^{2}-c} & =|-f| \\
\Rightarrow & & g^{2}+f^{2}-c & =f^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & & g^{2} & =c \ldots \tag{3}
\end{align*}
$$

We now use equations (1) and (2) to eliminate $f$.
(1): $4 g-2 f+c=-5$
(1) $\times 2: \quad 8 g-4 f+2 c=-10$
(2): $6 g-4 f+c=-13$
(2): $\begin{aligned} 6 g-4 f+c & =-13 \\ 2 g+c & =3 \\ \Rightarrow c & =-2 g+3\end{aligned}$

We now substitute $(-2 g+3)$ for $c$ in equation (3)
(3): $g^{2}=c$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & & g^{2} & =-2 g+3 \\
\Rightarrow & & g^{2}+2 g-3 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & (g-1)(g+3) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & g=1 \text { or } g & =-3
\end{aligned}
$$

$g=1 \Rightarrow c=-2(1)+3 \Rightarrow c=1$
$g=-3 \Rightarrow c=-2(-3)+3 \Rightarrow c=9$
Substituting these values for $g$ and $c$ in equation (1) we get:

$$
4 g-2 f+c=-5 \ldots
$$

$$
\begin{array}{llrl}
g=1 \text { and } c=1: & & 4(1)-2 f+1=-5 \\
& \Rightarrow & -2 f=-10 \Rightarrow f=5 \\
g=-3 \text { and } c=9 & \Rightarrow & 4(-3)-2 f+9=-5 \\
& \Rightarrow & -12-2 f+9=-5 \\
& \Rightarrow & -2 f=-2 \quad \Rightarrow \quad f=1
\end{array}
$$

The two sets of values for $g, f$ and $c$ are
Circle 1: $g=1, f=5$ and $c=1 \quad$ Circle 2: $\quad g=-3, f=1$ and $c=9$
Circle 1: $\quad x^{2}+y^{2}+2 x+10 y+1=0$
Circle 2: $\quad x^{2}+y^{2}-6 x+2 y+9=0$

## 12 Algebra 3

## Key words

inequality quadratic inequality rational inequality modulus modular equations modular inequalities direct proof proof by contradiction absolute value abstract inequalities indices base number exponential growth exponential decay logarithm proof by induction

## Section 12.1 Revision

The inequality symbols $>, \geqslant,<, \leqslant$ are needed when solving problems in which a range of possible values satisfy the given conditions.
e.g. If $3 x-4>5$,

$$
3 x>9,
$$

and $x>3$, which means that all values of $\boldsymbol{x}$ greater than 3 satisfy $3 x-4>5$.
$>$ greater than
$\geqslant$ greater than or equal to
$<$ less than
$\leqslant$ less than or equal to

An expression such as $3 x-4>5$ is called an inequality.

## Basic rules of inequalities

| Adding or subtracting a <br> constant, $a$ | $x>y$ | $x \pm a>y \pm a$ |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
| Multiplying or dividing <br> by a positive number, <br> $a>0$ | $x>y$ | $a x>a y$ |
|  |  | $\frac{x}{a}>\frac{y}{a}$ |

When multiplying or dividing by a negative number, the inequality symbol is reversed.
E.g. $5>2$; if both sides are multiplied by ( -1 ), we get $5 \times(-1)<2 \times(-1)$, i.e. $-5<-2$.

| Multiplying or dividing <br> by a negative number, <br> $a<0$ | $x>y$ | $a x<a y$ <br> $\frac{x}{a}<\frac{y}{a}$ |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |

Also,

| Combining inequalities | $x>y$ <br> $y>z$ | $x>z$ |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
|  | $x>y>0$ | $a x>b y$ |
|  | $a>b>0$ |  |

## Graphical construction

If a graph of the function is given or is easily constructed, this provides an extra technique in helping to understand and solve inequalities.

If $\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=(\boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3})(\boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{1})(\boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{4}) \geqslant \mathbf{0}$,
then the points $x=-3, x=1$ and $x=4$ are the critical points in determining the solution set.

The set of values of $x$ for which

$$
f(x)=(x+3)(x-1)(x-4) \geqslant 5
$$

can also be estimated.

## Note:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-461.jpg?height=447&width=609&top_left_y=592&top_left_x=1020)
(i) When solving inequalities, the solution is often restricted to specific number systems, i.e. $\in N, \in Z, \in R$, and the resulting range of numbers plotted on the number line. e.g. $5 x-1>14, x \in N$.
(ii) An inequality creates an ordered pair ( $a, b$ );

If $a>b$, then if the order is reversed ( $b, a$ ), the inequality is also reversed, i.e. $b<a$.

## Example 1

Solve the inequality $3 x+7 \geqslant x+2, x \in Z$, and plot the solution on a number line.

$$
\begin{aligned}
3 x+7 & \geqslant x+2 \\
2 x+7 & \geqslant 2 \ldots \text { subtracting } x \text { from both sides } \\
2 x & \geqslant-5 \ldots \text { subtracting } 7 \text { from both sides } \\
x & \geqslant \frac{-5}{2}, x \in Z .
\end{aligned}
$$

(All integer values greater than or equal to $-2 \frac{1}{2}$ will satisfy the original inequality.)
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-461.jpg?height=60&width=918&top_left_y=1799&top_left_x=451)

## Example 2

Solve the inequality $\frac{1}{6}(x-1) \geqslant \frac{1}{3}(x-4), x \in \mathrm{R}$.
Graph your solution on a number line.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{6}(x-1) \geqslant \frac{1}{3}(x-4) \\
& \Rightarrow x-1 \geqslant 2 x-8 \ldots \text { multiplying both sides by } 6 \\
& \Rightarrow-x \geqslant-7 \ldots \text { adding } 1 \text { and subtracting } 2 x \text { from both sides } \\
& \Rightarrow x \leqslant 7 \ldots \text { multiplying both sides by }(-1) \text { and reversing the inequality sign. }
\end{aligned}
$$

(Note: A closed circle on 7 indicates that 7 is included in the range.)

## Example 3

Solve the inequality $-9<3-4 x \leqslant 1, x \in \mathrm{R}$.
Graph your solution on the number line.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \begin{aligned}
-9<3-4 x & \leqslant 1 \\
\Rightarrow-12<-4 x & \leqslant-2
\end{aligned} \quad \ldots \text { subtracting } 3 \text { from each part of the inequality } \\
& \quad \Rightarrow 3>x \geqslant \frac{1}{2} \quad \ldots \text { dividing each part of the inequality by }-4 \text { and reversing } \\
& \quad \text { the inequality symbol } \\
& \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \leqslant x<3 \quad \ldots \text { reversing the order } \\
& \hdashline-1 \quad-0.5 \quad 0 \quad 1 \quad 0.5 \quad 1 \quad 1.5 \quad 2
\end{aligned}
$$

(Note: An open circle on 3 indicates that it is not to be included.)

## Example 4

(i) Find the solution set $A,\{x \mid 7 \leqslant 10-3 x, x \in R\}$.
(ii) Find the solution set $B,\left\{x \left\lvert\, 2>\frac{4}{3}-2 x\right., x \in R\right\}$.
(iii) Find the set $A \cap B$ and graph the solution on the number line.

$$
\begin{aligned}
A: 7 & \leqslant 10-3 x \\
3 x & \leqslant 3 \\
x & \leqslant 1
\end{aligned} \left\lvert\, \begin{aligned}
B: 2 & >\frac{4}{3}-2 x \\
2 x & >\frac{4}{3}-2 \\
2 x & >\frac{-2}{3} \\
x & >\frac{-1}{3}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

$\therefore \quad A \cap B$ is the set of values $\frac{-1}{3}<x \leqslant 1$.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-462.jpg?height=60&width=753&top_left_y=2087&top_left_x=533)

## Section 12.2 Quadratic and rational inequalities

## 1. Quadratic inequalities

$\boldsymbol{a} \boldsymbol{x}^{\mathbf{2}}+\boldsymbol{b} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{c} \geqslant \mathbf{0}$ is an example of a quadratic inequality.
To solve a quadratic inequality of the form $a x^{2}+b x+c \geqslant 0$ (or $\leqslant 0$ ), proceed as follows:

1. Solve $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ to find the (real) roots of the quadratic equation.
2. Draw a rough sketch of the graph using these roots.
(i) If $a>0$, the graph is $\cup$-shaped.
(ii) If $a<0$, the graph is $\cap$-shaped.
3. Use the graph to find the set of values of $x$ that satisfies the inequality.

## Example 1

Solve the inequality $x^{2}-2 x-8 \leqslant 0$.
Step 1. Solve $x^{2}-2 x-8=0$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow x^{2}-2 x-8=(x+2)(x-4)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow x=-2 \text { or } x=4
\end{aligned}
$$

Step 2. Since $a=+1$, i.e. $>0, \therefore a \cup$-shaped graph.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-464.jpg?height=413&width=640&top_left_y=1637&top_left_x=590)

Step 3. The solution of the inequality is the set of values of $x$ that produces the points of the graph that are on or below the $x$-axis, i.e. $x^{2}-2 x-8 \leqslant 0$. The solution is $-2 \leqslant x \leqslant 4$.

Questions involving values for which the roots of an equation are real, i.e. $b^{2}-4 a c \geqslant 0$, result in quadratic inequalities as shown in the following example.

## Example 2

Find the range of values of $k$ for which the equation $x^{2}+(k-4) x+(k-1)=0$ has real roots.

Condition for real roots: $b^{2}-4 a c \geqslant 0$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a=1, b=(k-4), c=(k-1) \\
& \Rightarrow b^{2}-4 a c=(k-4)^{2}-4(1)(k-1) \\
& \quad=k^{2}-8 k+16-4 k+4 \\
& \quad=k^{2}-12 k+20
\end{aligned} \quad \begin{aligned}
b^{2}-4 a c \geqslant 0 & \Rightarrow k^{2}-12 k+20 \geqslant 0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-465.jpg?height=449&width=661&top_left_y=504&top_left_x=900)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { (i) Solving } k^{2}-12 k+20=0 \text {; } \\
& \Rightarrow(k-2)(k-10)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow k=2 \text { and } k=10 \text { are the roots. }
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) Sketch the graph; $a=+1$, i.e. $>0$, $\therefore$ a $\cup$-shaped graph.

The solution of the inequality is the set of values of $k$ that produces points on a graph that are on or above the $k$-axis, i.e. $k^{2}-12 k+20 \geqslant 0$.
The solution is $k \leqslant 2$ and $k \geqslant 10$.

## 2. Rational inequalities

$f(x)=\frac{3 x-2}{x+1}$ is a rational function as the denominator and numerator are both polynomials in $x$.
$\frac{3 x-2}{x+1} \geqslant 2$ is a rational inequality.
Since we do not know if ( $x+1$ ) is positive or negative, we cannot simply multiply both sides by ( $x+1$ ) when solving for $x$ as the inequality symbol would have to be reversed if ( $x+1$ ) was negative.

However, if we multiply both sides by $(x+1)^{2}$, we can retain the same inequality sign since $(x+1)^{2}$ is always positive.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \frac{3 x-2}{x+1} \times(x+1)^{2} \geqslant 2 \times(x+1)^{2} \\
& \Rightarrow(3 x-2)(x+1) \geqslant 2\left(x^{2}+2 x+1\right) \\
& \Rightarrow 3 x^{2}+x-2 \geqslant 2 x^{2}+4 x+2 \\
& \Rightarrow x^{2}-3 x-4 \geqslant 0, \quad \text { creating a quadratic inequality (with the same solution set) } \\
& \quad \text { from the rational inequality. }
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 3

Find the range of values of $x$ for which $\frac{2 x+1}{x+2}<\frac{1}{2}$.
Since $\frac{2 x+1}{x+2}<\frac{1}{2}$,
multiply both sides by $(x+2)^{2}$.
$\left[(x+2)^{2}\right.$ is always positive for all values of $x$.]
$\Rightarrow \frac{2 x+1}{x+2} \times(x+2)^{2}<\frac{1}{2} \times(x+2)^{2}$
$\Rightarrow(2 x+1)(x+2)<\frac{1}{2}\left(x^{2}+4 x+4\right)$
$\Rightarrow 2 x^{2}+5 x+2<\frac{1}{2}\left(x^{2}+4 x+4\right)$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-466.jpg?height=446&width=555&top_left_y=376&top_left_x=1017)
$\Rightarrow 4 x^{2}+10 x+4<x^{2}+4 x+4$
$\Rightarrow 3 x^{2}+6 x<0$
$\Rightarrow x^{2}+2 x<0$.
[Note: $\frac{2 x+1}{x+2}<\frac{1}{2}$ has the same solution set as $x^{2}+2 x<0$.]
(i) Solving the equation $x^{2}+2 x=0$;
(ii) Sketch the graph; $a=+1$, i.e. $>0$,
$\Rightarrow(x)(x+2)=0$
$\therefore \quad$ a $\cup$-shaped graph.
$\Rightarrow x=0$ and $x=-2$ are the roots.
$\Rightarrow$ The solution of the inequality is the set values of $x$ that produces points on the graph that are below the $x$-axis (i.e. $x^{2}+2 x<0$ ).
The solution is $-2<x<0$.

## Section 12.3 Modulus

## 1. Modular equations

The modulus of a number is a measure of its size or magnitude and is written as $|x|$.
$|3|=3,|-4|=4,|15.5|=15.5,|-6.2|=6.2 \ldots$ in other words, for all $x \in R,|x|$ is the positive value of the number.

If $|x|=a$, then $x=+a$ or $-a$ and $|x|^{2}=a^{2}$.

Conversely, if $|x|=6$, then $x=+6$ or -6 .
And therefore, $|x|^{2}=36$.
Geometrically, the modulus function multiplies any negative part of the graph by $(-1)$.
Compare the following graphs:
$y=x$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-469.jpg?height=310&width=307&top_left_y=920&top_left_x=273)
$y=|x|$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-469.jpg?height=310&width=307&top_left_y=920&top_left_x=603)
$y=2 x-3$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-469.jpg?height=357&width=308&top_left_y=920&top_left_x=933)
$y=|2 x-3|$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-469.jpg?height=357&width=308&top_left_y=920&top_left_x=1263)

The graph of $f(x)=|x|$ is found from the graph of $f(x)=x$ by reflecting, in the $x$-axis, that part of the graph for which $f(x)<0$.

## Example 1

Sketch the graph of $f(x)=|3 x+5|$ and hence solve the equation $|3 x+5|=2$
(i) graphically and
(ii) algebraically.
(i) Graphically:

Given $f(x)=3 x+5$.
At $x=0, f(x)=5 \Rightarrow(0,5)$ is the $f(x)$ intercept.
At $f(x)=0 ; 0=3 x+5 \Rightarrow x=\frac{-5}{3} \Rightarrow\left(\frac{-5}{3}, 0\right)$ is the $x$-axis intercept.
$f(x)=3 x+5$ is the line passing through $(0,5)$ and $\left(\frac{-5}{3}, 0\right)$.

Reflecting the negative region of the graph in the $x$-axis creates the graph of $f(x)=|3 x+5|$.

The $x$-coordinates of the intersection points of $f(x)=|3 x+5|$ and $f(x)=2$ give the solution to the equation $|3 x+5|=2$.
The $x$-coordinates are $x=-1$ and $x \cong-2.3$.
(ii) Algebraically:

## Method 1

Since $|3 x+5|=2$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow 3 x+5=+2 \quad \therefore x=-1 \\
& \text { or } 3 x+5=-2 \quad \therefore x=\frac{-7}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

The solution is $x=\frac{-7}{3}$ or $x=-1$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-470.jpg?height=500&width=485&top_left_y=238&top_left_x=1054)

## Method 2

$|3 x+5|=2$
$\Rightarrow(3 x+5)^{2}=(2)^{2}$
$\Rightarrow 9 x^{2}+30 x+25=4$
$\Rightarrow 9 x^{2}+30 x+21=0$
$\Rightarrow 3 x^{2}+10 x+7=0$
$\Rightarrow(3 x+7)(x+1)=0$
$\Rightarrow$ The solution is $\left(-\frac{7}{3},-1\right)$

Note 1: The method of "squaring both sides" of a modular equation can be useful when the modulus sign appears on both sides of the equation, e.g. $|3 x+5|=|x-2|$.

Note 2: Getting the modulus of an expression is sometimes referred to as getting the absolute value of the expression.

## 2. Modular inequalities

If $|x|<1$, then the value of $x$ must lie between +1 and -1 , i.e. $-1<x<+1$.
If $|x|>1$, then the value of $x$ must lie outside this range, i.e. $x>1$ or $x<-1$.

## Example 2

Sketch the graph of $f(x)=|2 x-5|$ and hence solve the inequality

$$
|2 x-5|<3
$$

$f(x)=2 x-5$ is drawn first by using two points on the line, e.g. $(2.5,0)$ and $(4,3)$.
$f(x)=|2 x-5|$ is then drawn by reflecting the negative portion of the graph in the $x$-axis as before.

Drawing the line $f(x)=3$ on the same axes, the red segment represents where $|2 x-5|<3$.

The $x$-values that create that portion of the
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-471.jpg?height=404&width=489&top_left_y=239&top_left_x=1054) graph are $1<x<4$.

Note: If $|2 x-5|=3$, then $2 x-5=3$ or $2 x-5=-3$.
If $|2 x-5|<3$, then $-3<2 x-5<3$.

$$
\begin{array}{rrl}
\therefore \quad & 2<2 x<8 & \ldots \text { adding } 5 \text { to each part of the inequality } \\
& 1<x<4 & \ldots \text { dividing each part of the inequality by } 2
\end{array}
$$

This produces the same solution set as above.

## Example 3

Draw a graph of $f(x)=|x+3|$ and $f(x)=|3 x-7|$.
Solve the inequality $|x+3|<|3 x-7|$ algebraically and indicate graphically the solution set.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |x+3|<|3 x-7| \\
\Rightarrow & (x+3)^{2}<(3 x-7)^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}+6 x+9<9 x^{2}-42 x+49 \\
\Rightarrow & -8 x^{2}+48 x-40<0 \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}-6 x+5>0
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-471.jpg?height=531&width=596&top_left_y=1408&top_left_x=942)

Solving $x^{2}-6 x+5=0$,
$(x-5)(x-1)=0$
$\Rightarrow x=5$ or $x=1$
Therefore, the values of $x$ for which $x^{2}-6 x+5>0$ are $x<1$ and $x>5$.

## Section 12.4 Mathematical proof

In mathematics, we use deductive reasoning to prove that a statement is always true.
The statement, when proved true, then becomes a theorem. e.g. Pythagoras' theorem.
The different methods of proof include direct proofs, proofs by contradiction and proofs by induction (see Section 12.12).

## 1. Direct proof

Direct proof uses axioms, definitions and other proven theorems to verify the new statement.

## Example 1

Prove that the sum of two even integers $x$ and $y$ is always even.

## Proof:

Since $x$ is even, we can write it as $x=2 a$, where $a \in Z$.
Also since $y$ is even, $y=2 b$, where $b \in Z$.
Therefore, $x+y=2 a+2 b=2(a+b)$.
Since $x+y$ has a factor of $2 \Rightarrow x+y$ must be even.
$\therefore$ The sum of two even integers is always even.

## 2. Proof by contradiction

In a proof by contradiction, we show that if we claim some statement to be true, then a logical contradiction occurs which proves that the original statement must be false.

## Example 2

Prove that $\sqrt{2}$ is irrational.
Proof: Assume $\sqrt{2}$ is a rational number.
$\therefore \quad \sqrt{2}$ can be written as $\frac{a}{b}: a, b \in Z$ and $b \neq 0$, and $a$ and $b$ have no common factor.
$\therefore \quad 2=\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}} \ldots$ squaring both sides
$\therefore \quad a^{2}=2 b^{2}$
$\therefore a^{2}$ is even since it is equal to $2 \times\left(b^{2}\right) \ldots$.any integer multiplied by 2 is even
$\therefore \quad a$ is even
$\therefore a$ can be written as $a=2 c \ldots$ since $a$ is divisible by 2
$\therefore \quad a^{2}=4 c^{2}=2 b^{2}$
$\therefore \quad 2 c^{2}=b^{2}$
$\therefore b$ is also even
$\therefore \quad a$ and $b$ have a common factor of 2 which contradicts our assumption.
$\therefore \sqrt{2}$ is not a rational number.
$\therefore \quad \sqrt{2}$ is an irrational number, i.e. it cannot be written as $\frac{a}{b}$ with no common factors.

## Section 12.5 Proofs of abstract inequalities

If $a>0$ and $b>0$, then $\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{a} \geqslant 2$ is an example of an abstract inequality (see Example 2).
To prove that an inequality statement is true, we will use two important facts:
(i) $(\text { Any real number })^{2} \geqslant 0$
(ii) $-(\text { Any real number })^{2} \leqslant 0$.

If both sides of an inequality are squared, the inequality sign is retained only if both sides of the inequality are positive.
For example, $4>3 \Rightarrow 4^{2}>3^{2}$, i.e. $16>9$.
However, if one or both sides are negative,

If $a$ and $b$ are real numbers, then

$$
\begin{gathered}
a^{2} \geqslant 0 \text { and } b^{2} \geqslant 0 \\
(a+b)^{2} \geqslant 0 \\
(a-b)^{2} \geqslant 0 \\
-(a+b)^{2} \leqslant 0 \\
-(a-b)^{2} \leqslant 0
\end{gathered}
$$ then this does not hold.

E.g. $\quad 2>-3 \nRightarrow 2^{2}>(-3)^{2}$, i.e. $4 \ngtr 9$.

To prove an abstract inequality;

1. Write down the statement you are asked to prove.
2. Use the rules of inequalities to adapt the inequality until ...
3. you arrive at an inequality that is obviously true.

## Example 1

Prove that $a^{2}+b^{2} \geqslant 2 a b$ for all $a, b \in R$.
If: $a^{2}+b^{2} \geqslant 2 a b$,
then $a^{2}-2 a b+b^{2} \geqslant 0 \ldots$ subtracting $2 a b$ from both sides.
$\therefore(a-b)^{2} \geqslant 0 \ldots$ factorising the left-hand side.
which is always true. $\quad \therefore a^{2}+b^{2} \geqslant 2 a b$.

## Example 2

If $a>0$ and $b>0$, prove that $\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{a} \geqslant 2$.
If: $\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{a} \geqslant 2$,
then $a^{2}+b^{2} \geqslant 2 a b \ldots$ multiply each term by the common denominator $a b$.
$\therefore \quad a^{2}-2 a b+b^{2} \geqslant 0$
$\therefore \quad(a-b)^{2} \geqslant 0 \ldots$ which is always true.

$$
\therefore \quad \frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{a} \geqslant 2 .
$$

## Example 3

Show that $x^{2}+4 x+6>0$ (i.e. is positive) for all $x \in R$.
If: $x^{2}+4 x+6>0$,
then $x^{2}+4 x+4-4+6>0 \quad \ldots$ adding and subtracting $\left(\frac{4}{2}\right)^{2}$ to complete the square.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow(x+2)^{2}-4+6>0 \quad \ldots \text { completing the square. } \\
& \quad \Rightarrow \quad(x+2)^{2}+2>0 \quad \ldots \text { which is true for all values of } x, \text { since }(x+2)^{2}>0 \\
& \quad \text { for all values of } x . \\
& \quad \therefore \quad x^{2}+4 x+6>0 \text { for all } x \in R .
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 4

Show for all real numbers $a, b>0$ that $(a+b)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}\right) \geqslant 4$.
If: $(a+b)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}\right) \geqslant 4$,
then $(a+b)\left(\frac{a+b}{a b}\right) \geqslant 4 \ldots$ using the common denominator $a b$ to add the fractions.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad \frac{(a+b)^{2}}{a b} & \geqslant 4 \ldots \text { simplifying. } \\
\therefore \quad(a+b)^{2} & \geqslant 4 a b \ldots \text { multiplying both sides by } a b . \\
\therefore \quad a^{2}+2 a b+b^{2} & \geqslant 4 a b \ldots \text { expanding the left-hand side. } \\
\therefore \quad a^{2}-2 a b+b^{2} & \geqslant 0 \ldots \text { subtracting } 4 a b \text { from both sides. } \\
\therefore \quad & \therefore \quad(a-b)^{2}
\end{aligned} \geqslant 0 \ldots \text { which is true for all } a, b \in R .
$$

## Section 12.6 Indices

When a number is multiplied by itself many times, we use the index form to represent the product.
$4 \times 4 \times 4 \times 4 \times 4=4^{5}$, i.e. 4 to the power of 5 .
In this case, 5 is the index (plural indices) and 4 is the base number.

## Revision of the rules of indices.

|  | Example | Rule |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| 1. | $6^{3} \times 6^{4}=6^{7}$ | $a^{p} a^{q}=a^{p+q}$ |
| 2. | $\frac{4^{5}}{4^{2}}=4^{3}$, also $\frac{4^{5}}{4^{7}}=4^{-2}$ | $\frac{a^{p}}{a^{q}}=a^{p-q}$ |
| 3. | $\left(2^{4}\right)^{3}=2^{12}$ | $\left(a^{p}\right)^{q}=a^{p q}$ |
| 4. | $3^{0}=5^{0}=9^{0}=(-3)^{0}=\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{0}=1$ | $a^{0}=1$ |
| 5. | $3^{-1}=\frac{1}{3}, 3^{-4}=\frac{1}{3^{4}}$ | $a^{-p}=\frac{1}{a^{p}}$ |
| 6. | $7^{\frac{1}{2}}=\sqrt[2]{7}, 5^{\frac{1}{3}}=\sqrt[3]{5}$ | $a^{\frac{1}{q}}=\sqrt[q]{a}$ |
| 7. | $8^{\frac{2}{3}}=\left(8^{\frac{1}{3}}\right)^{2}$ or $\left(8^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}$ | $a^{\frac{p}{q}}=\sqrt[q]{a^{p}}=(\sqrt[q]{a})^{p}$ |
| 8. | $\begin{aligned} & (2 \times 5)^{2}=2^{2} \times 5^{2} \\ & \left(\frac{5}{6}\right)^{4}=\frac{5^{4}}{6^{4}} \end{aligned}$ | $\begin{aligned} & (a b)^{p}=a^{p} a^{p} \\ & \left(\frac{a}{b}\right)^{p}=\frac{a^{p}}{b^{p}} \end{aligned}$ |

Each of these rules can be verified by expanding the powers and simplifying, e.g.

$$
\left(2^{4}\right)^{3}=2^{4} \times 2^{4} \times 2^{4}=2^{12}=4096
$$

Note: $\sqrt{x}=\sqrt[2]{x}=x^{\frac{1}{2}}=$ the square root of $x$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sqrt[3]{x}=x^{\frac{1}{3}}=\text { the cube root of } x \\
& \sqrt[4]{x}=x^{\frac{1}{4}}=\text { the fourth root of } x \ldots \text { etc. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Note: $25^{\frac{3}{2}}=\left(25^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{3}=(5)^{3}=125$ (most often, it is easier to get the root first and then raise to the power.)

## Example 1

Evaluate each of the following.
(i) $27^{\frac{1}{3}}$
(ii) $36^{\frac{3}{2}}$
(iii) $64^{-\frac{2}{3}}$
(iv) $\left(\frac{27}{125}\right)^{-\frac{2}{3}}$
(i) $27^{\frac{1}{3}}=\sqrt[3]{27}=3 \ldots$ (i.e. 3 multiplied by itself three times equals 27 )
(ii) $36^{\frac{3}{2}}=\left(36^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{3}=(\sqrt{36})^{3}=6^{3}=216$
(iii) $64^{-\frac{2}{3}}=\frac{1}{64^{\frac{2}{3}}}=\frac{1}{\left(64^{\frac{1}{3}}\right)^{2}}=\frac{1}{(4)^{2}}=\frac{1}{16}$
(iv) $\left(\frac{27}{125}\right)^{-\frac{2}{3}}=\left(\frac{125}{27}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}=\left[\left(\frac{125}{27}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\right]^{2}=\left(\frac{5}{3}\right)^{2}=\frac{25}{9}$

Numerical expressions containing complex fractions with indices can be simplified and evaluated with a calculator.

Since the procedure on each calculator may be slightly different, it is important to gain practice on your calculator, particularly when dealing with fractional powers.

However, it is most important to understand the rules of indices and to be able to apply them to general problems containing unknowns.

## Example 2

Simplify each of the following.
(i) $\left(\frac{x^{2} y^{-3}}{x^{-4} y^{5}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$
(ii) $\frac{\sqrt{a^{3}}}{\sqrt[4]{a} \times \sqrt[3]{a^{2}}}$
(i) $\left(\frac{x^{2} y^{-3}}{x^{-4} y^{5}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}=\left(x^{6} y^{-8}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}=\left(x^{6}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(y^{-8}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}=x^{3} y^{-4}=\frac{x^{3}}{y^{4}}$
(ii) $\frac{\sqrt{a^{3}}}{\sqrt[4]{a} \times \sqrt[3]{a^{2}}}=\frac{a^{\frac{3}{2}}}{a^{\frac{1}{4}} \times a^{\frac{2}{3}}}=\frac{a^{\frac{3}{2}}}{a^{\frac{3+8}{12}}}=\frac{a^{\frac{3}{2}}}{a^{\frac{11}{12}}}=a^{\frac{3}{2}-\frac{11}{12}}=a^{\frac{7}{12}}$

## Example 3

Show that $\frac{5^{n+1}-4.5^{n}}{5^{n-2}+5^{n}}=\frac{25}{26}$.
$\frac{5^{n+1}-4.5^{n}}{5^{n-2}+5^{n}}=\frac{5^{n} \cdot 5^{1}-4.5^{n}}{5^{n} \cdot 5^{-2}+5^{n}}=\frac{5.5^{n}-4.5^{n}}{\frac{5^{n}}{25}+5^{n}}=\frac{5^{n}}{\frac{5^{n}+25.5^{n}}{25}}=\frac{5^{n}}{\frac{26.5^{n}}{25}}=\frac{25}{26}$

## Section 12.7 Exponential equations

$\qquad$
$y=3^{x}$ is an example of an exponential function.
$3^{x}=27$ is an example of an exponential equation.
As in the last section, 3 is the base number and $x$ is the index (power) or exponent.
When solving exponential equations, it is important to identify the base number (usually a prime number) that is common to all the individual terms of the equation.
E.g. $3^{x}=27$; 3 is the base number for both sides. ... $\left(3^{x}=3^{3}\right)$
$25^{x}=125 ; 5$ is the base number. ... $\left(5^{x}=5^{3}\right)$

## Example 1

Solve these equations. (i) $\frac{1}{8^{x}}=16^{\frac{1}{3}} \quad$ (ii) $27^{x-3}=3 \times 9^{x-2}$
(i) $\frac{1}{8^{x}}=16^{\frac{1}{3}}$ (the base number is 2)
(ii) $27^{x-3}=3 \times 9^{x-2}$
(the base number is 3 )

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{\left(2^{3}\right)^{x}}=\left(2^{4}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} \\
& \begin{aligned}
2^{-3 x}=2^{\frac{4}{3}} & \Rightarrow-3 x=\frac{4}{3} \\
& \Rightarrow x=-\frac{4}{9}
\end{aligned}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(3^{3}\right)^{x-3} & =3 \times\left(3^{2}\right)^{x-2} \\
\Rightarrow 3^{3 x-9} & =3^{1} \times 3^{2 x-4} \\
\Rightarrow 3^{3 x-9} & =3^{2 x-3} \\
\Rightarrow 3 x-9 & =2 x-3 \\
\Rightarrow x & =6
\end{aligned}
$$

By using a suitable change of variable, an exponential equation can be transformed into a

Note: If $2^{x}=y$, quadratic equation and then solved.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow 3 \cdot 2^{x}=3 y \\
& \Rightarrow 2^{2 x}=\left(2^{x}\right)^{2}=y^{2} \\
& \Rightarrow 2^{x+2}=2^{x} \cdot 2^{2}=4 y
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 2

If $y=3^{x}$, express $3^{2 x}$ in terms of $y$.
Hence solve the equation $3^{2 x}-4.3^{x}+3=0$.
(i) $3^{2 x}=\left(3^{x}\right)^{2}=y^{2}$
(ii) Given $3^{2 x}-4.3^{x}+3=0$.
$\Rightarrow y^{2}-4 y+3=0 \ldots$ using the substitution $3^{x}=y$ and $3^{2 x}=y^{2}$
$\Rightarrow(y-1)(y-3)=0$
$\Rightarrow y=1$ or $y=3 \ldots$ are the solutions of the new quadratic equation
$\Rightarrow 3^{x}=1$ or $3^{x}=3 \ldots$ re-substituting to find values of $x$
$\Rightarrow 3^{x}=3^{0}$ or $3^{x}=3^{1} \ldots$ using the base number 3
$\therefore x=0$ or $x=1$ are the solutions.

## Section 12.8 Exponential functions

Exponential functions such as $\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=\boldsymbol{a}^{\boldsymbol{x}}$ are used in modelling many physical occurrences.
These include:
(i) the growth of a biological cell
(ii) changes in population, e.g. algae growth on stagnant water
(iii) compounded interest and depreciation
(iv) radioactive decay
(v) the rate at which a body loses heat (Newton's law of cooling).

ICT: Functions of the form $y=a^{x}, a=$ constant, can be studied graphically. Remember, when using a keyboard, to use the "^" button to raise a power (exponent), i.e. $y=2^{\wedge} x$.
Proper use of brackets is essential, i.e. $y=2^{\wedge}(2 x)=2^{2 x}$.

All of the graphs associated with exponential functions have a characteristic shape and are easily identified. From this diagram we can see that graphs of the form $\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=\boldsymbol{a}^{\boldsymbol{x}}$, where $a>0$ and $a \neq 1$, have the following properties;

1. At $x=0, f(0)=a^{0}=1$.
$\Rightarrow(0,1)$ is a point on all graphs.
2. At $x=1, f(1)=a^{1}=a$.
$\Rightarrow(1, a)$ is a point on all graphs.
3. At $x=-1, f(-1)=a^{-1}=\frac{1}{a}$.
$\Rightarrow\left(-1, \frac{1}{a}\right)$ is a point on all graphs.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-484.jpg?height=512&width=614&top_left_y=1682&top_left_x=1018)
4. They are defined for all real values of $x$.
5. The $x$-axis is a horizontal asymptote to all the curves $\Rightarrow f(x)=a^{x}$ is always positive.
6. If $\boldsymbol{a}>\mathbf{1}$, all of the curves increase as $x$ increases. As $a$ increases, the curves rise more steeply.
7. If $\mathbf{0}<\boldsymbol{a}<\mathbf{1}$, then the curve $f(x)=a^{x}$ reflects in the $y$-axis, producing a set of curves that decrease rapidly as $x$ increases.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-485.jpg?height=485&width=600&top_left_y=177&top_left_x=1037)

Note: If $a=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=2^{-1}$

$$
\Rightarrow f(x)=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{x}=\left(2^{-1}\right)^{x}=2^{-x}
$$

Note: The general formula for an increasing exponential function is $f(x)=\mathrm{A} a^{x}$, where A is the value at the start, i.e. when $x=0$.

Exponential functions $f(x)=\mathrm{A} \cdot a^{x}$
Increasing exponential functions $a>1$.
Decreasing exponential functions $0<a<1$. $(0, \mathrm{~A})$ is the $y$-axis intercept.
Decreasing functions can be written in the form

$$
f(x)=\mathrm{A} \cdot a^{-x}
$$

The magnitude (or size) $M$ of an earthquake is measured on a scale called the Richter scale.
During earthquakes, the amplitude $(A)$ of the earth's movement is a measure of the intensity $(I)$ of the quake i.e. $I \sim A$ and is given by the exponential formula $I=k 10^{M}$, where $k$ is a constant.
The energy released by the earthquake of magnitude $M$ is $E=10^{1.5 M+4.4}$ joules

An earthquake of magnitude 2 on the Richter scale releases $25,118,864$ Joules of energy.
An earthquake of magnitude 6 on the Richter scale releases 25,118,864,315,096 Joules of energy.

## Example 3

Given that the intensity of an earthquake is represented by the formula $I=k 10^{M}$, and the energy released during a quake by the formula $\mathrm{E} \cong 10^{1.5 M+4.8}$, where $I$ is the Intensity and $M$ is the magnitude on the Richter scale, compare
(i) the intensity
(ii) the energy of an earthquake of magnitude 6.1 on the Richter scale with a quake of magnitude 4.7.
(i) $M_{1}=6.1 \Rightarrow I_{1}=k 10^{6.1}$
$M_{2}=4.7 \Rightarrow I_{2}=k 10^{4.7}$
$\Rightarrow \frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}=\frac{k 10^{6.1}}{k 10^{4.7}}=10^{1.4} \cong 25$
$\Rightarrow I_{1} \cong 25 I_{2}$
(ii) $\mathrm{E}_{1} \cong 10^{1.5 M+4.8}=10^{1.5 \times 6.1+4.8}=10^{13.95}$
$\mathrm{E}_{2} \cong 10^{1.5 M+4.8}=10^{1.5 \times 4.7+4.8}=10^{11.85}$
$\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{E}_{1}}{\mathrm{E}_{2}}=\frac{10^{13.95}}{10^{11.85}}=10^{2.1} \cong 126$
$\mathrm{E}_{1} \cong 126 \mathrm{E}_{2}$

## Section 12.9 Logarithmic function

The logarithm is a function that focuses on the index (or exponent) of a number.
If $y=2^{5}$, then $y=32$ is easily calculated.
However, if $200=2^{x}$, it is not as easy to find the index $x$ that gives the number 200.
To find $x$, we use logarithms (logs for short).
Consider the result $32=2^{5}$; using $\log$ notation, $\log _{2} 32=5$.
This is read as "the $\log$ of 32 to the base 2 is 5 ", i.e., $\mathbf{5}$ is the index (power) to which the base number 2 must be raised to get 32 .

Similarly, $10^{2}=100$ can be rewritten using logs as $\log _{10} 100=2$ (the $\log$ of 100 in the base 10 is 2 ),
i.e., $\mathbf{2}$ is the index (power) to which the base number 10 must be raised to get 100 .

Thus, the equations $2^{3}=8$ and $\log _{2} 8=3$ are identical and interchangeable.

| Index form | $\log$ form |
| :---: | :--- |
| $32=2^{5}$ | $\log _{2} 32=5$ |
| $100=10^{2}$ | $\log _{10} 100=2$ |
| $200=2^{x}$ | $\log _{2} 200=x$ |

The logarithm of a number is the power to which the base number must be raised to get that number. $\boldsymbol{a}^{\boldsymbol{x}}=\boldsymbol{y}$ is equivalent to $\boldsymbol{\operatorname { l o g }}_{\boldsymbol{a}} \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{x}$

From this definition of a log, it is clear that
(i) $\log _{5} 25=2$
(ii) $\log _{3} 27=3$
(iii) $\log _{2} 16=4$
(iv) $\log _{3} 81=4$,
i.e. to what power must 5 be raised, to get $25 \ldots$ ? Answer $=2 \ldots$ etc.

If the log or base is not a whole number, proceed as follows.

## 1. The laws of logarithms

When the rules of indices are expressed in logarithm form, we produce the very important laws of logarithms.

These laws enable us to solve many complex equations.

Using your calculator, verify each of the following.

1. $\log _{10} 4+\log _{10} 3=\log _{10} 12=1.0792$

## The Laws of Logarithms

1. $\log _{a} x y=\log _{a} x+\log _{a} y$
2. $\log _{a}\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)=\log _{a} x-\log _{a} y$
3. $\log _{a} x^{n}=n \log _{a} x$
4. $\log _{a} a=1$
5. $\log _{a} 1=0$
6. $\log _{a} x=\frac{\log _{b} x}{\log _{b} a}$
7. $\log _{10} 8-\log _{10} 6=\log _{10}\left(\frac{8}{6}\right)=0.1249$
8. $\log _{10} 8^{3}=3 \log _{10} 8=2.7093$
9. $\log _{10} 10=1$
10. $\log _{10} 1=0$

The rules of logs apply to any base, however, the two most widely-used bases in logs are the base 10 and the base e (2.718).

Base ten logs, e.g. $\log _{\mathbf{1 0}} \mathbf{1 0 0 0}$, are used for calculation purposes and are referred to as common logs.

Base $e(=2.718)$, e.g. $\log _{e} 1000$, is used when dealing with naturally-occurring events, e.g. earthquakes, growth of colonies etc., and hence are called natural logs and are written $\boldsymbol{\operatorname { l o g }}_{\boldsymbol{e}} \boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{\operatorname { l n }} \boldsymbol{x}$.

## Example 2

Without using a calculator, simplify the following number:

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 \log _{10} 3+\log _{10} 16-2 \log _{10}\left(\frac{6}{5}\right) & \\
2 \log _{10} 3+\log _{10} 16-2 \log _{10}\left(\frac{6}{5}\right) & =\log _{10} 3^{2}+\log _{10} 16-\log _{10}\left(\frac{6}{5}\right)^{2} \\
& =\log _{10}\left(3^{2} \times 16\right)-\log _{10}\left(\frac{36}{25}\right) \\
& =\log _{10} \frac{9 \times 16}{\left(\frac{36}{25}\right)} \\
& =\log _{10} 100=2
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 3

Without using a calculator, simplify the following number:

$$
\log _{2} 128+\log _{3} 45-\log _{3} 5
$$

$\log _{2} 128+\log _{3} 45-\log _{3} 5=\log _{2} 128+\log _{3}\left(\frac{45}{5}\right)=\log _{2} 128+\log _{3} 9$
(Since the bases are different, these logs cannot be added!)
Let $\log _{2} 128=x \Rightarrow 128=2^{x}$ also, let $\log _{3} 9=y \Rightarrow 9=3^{y}$
$2^{7}=2^{x}$
$3^{2}=3^{y}$
$7=x$
$2=y$
$\therefore \quad \log _{2} 128+\log _{3} 9=7+2=9$

If $e$ is a positive integer, $\mathrm{e} \geqslant 2, k>0 \quad$ (i) $\log _{\mathrm{e}}(\mathrm{e})^{k}=k$ and (ii) $e^{\left(\log _{\mathrm{e}} k\right)}=k$

## 2. Solving logarithmic equations

- When solving log equations, always check that each term has the same base. If this is not the case, the change of base rule must first be used to change to a common base.
- If no base is given, the equation holds true for all bases.
- If $\log _{a} b=\log _{a} c$, then $b=c$.
- If $\log _{a} b=k$, then $b=a^{k}$.
- Check all solutions to make sure they do not produce logs of negative numbers as these are not defined. (See page 492.)


## Example 5

Solve the equation $2 \log _{3} x-\log _{3}(18-x)=1$.
$2 \log _{3} x-\log _{3}(18-x)=1$
$\Rightarrow \log _{3} x^{2}-\log _{3}(18-x)=1$
$\Rightarrow \log _{3}\left(\frac{x^{2}}{18-x}\right)=1$
$\Rightarrow\left(\frac{x^{2}}{18-x}\right)=3^{1}=3$
$\Rightarrow x^{2}=54-3 x$
$\Rightarrow x^{2}+3 x-54=0$
$\Rightarrow(x-6)(x+9)=0$
$\Rightarrow x=6$ or $x=-9$.

If $x=-9$, the equation becomes

$$
2 \log _{3}(-9)-\log _{3}(18+9)=1
$$

Since the $\log _{3}(-9)$ is undefined, $x=-9$ is rejected as an answer.
$\Rightarrow x=6$.

## Example 6

Solve the equation $\log _{3} x+3 \log _{x} 3=4$.
This equation contains logs with different bases.
Therefore, we need to change base 3 to base $x$ (or vice versa).
$\log _{3} x=\frac{\log _{x} x}{\log _{x} 3}=\frac{1}{\log _{x} 3}$ because $\log _{x} x=1$
$\therefore \log _{3} x+3 \log _{x} 3=4 \Rightarrow \frac{1}{\log _{x} 3}+3 \log _{x} 3=4$
Using the substitution $\log _{x} 3=y$,

$$
\begin{array}{l|l}
\quad \frac{1}{y}+3 y=4 & \therefore \log _{x} 3=1 \Rightarrow 3=x^{1} \\
\Rightarrow 1+3 y^{2}=4 y & \Rightarrow 3=x \\
3 y^{2}-4 y+1=0 & \text { or } \log _{x} 3=\frac{1}{3}
\end{array} \Rightarrow 3=x^{\frac{1}{3}}=\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow 3^{3}=x \\
& (3 y-1)(y-1)=0 \\
& \therefore \quad y=1 \text { or } y=\frac{1}{3}
\end{aligned} \quad \begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow 27=x
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad x=3$ or 27 (both solutions give positive logs and thus are acceptable).
(Note: This result can be verified by repeating the procedure using the base 3 instead of the base $\left.x: \log _{x} 3=\frac{\log _{3} 3}{\log _{3} x}=\frac{1}{\log _{3} x}\right)$.

Using computer software, the graphs of $\log _{10}(x), \log _{e}(x)$ [i.e. $\ln (x)$ ] and $\log _{2}(x)$ are drawn in the domain $0 \leqslant x \leqslant 10$.
Comparing the graphs, we conclude that $y=\log _{a}(x)$ has the following properties:

1. $\log _{\text {(any base) }} 1=0$.
2. $\log _{2} 2=\log _{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{e}=\log _{10} 10=1$.
3. All graphs of log functions are increasing.

## Comparing $\log _{a}(x)$ with $y=a^{x}$

If we let $a=2$; comparing $y=2^{x}$ and $y=\log _{2}(x)$, we have

| $\boldsymbol{x}$ | $\boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2}^{\boldsymbol{x}}$ | $\boldsymbol{x}$ | $\boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{\operatorname { l o g }}_{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{x}$ |
| :---: | :--- | ---: | :--- |
| 0 | $y=2^{0}=1$ | 1 | $y=\log _{2} 1=0$ |
| 1 | $y=2^{1}=2$ | 2 | $y=\log _{2} 2=1$ |
| 2 | $y=2^{2}=4$ | 4 | $y=\log _{2} 4=2$ |
| 3 | $y=2^{3}=8$ | 8 | $y=\log _{2} 8=3$ |
| 4 | $y=2^{4}=16$ | 16 | $y=\log _{2} 16=4$ |

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2025_07_30_25efca13633dab4f44f5g-495.jpg?height=409&width=635&top_left_y=1766&top_left_x=993)

The points $(0,1),(1,2),(2,4),(3,8),(4,16), \ldots$ are on the curve $y=2^{x}$.
The points $(1,0),(2,1),(4,2),(8,3),(16,4), \ldots$ are on the curve $y=\log _{2}(x)$.
$\therefore \quad y=\log _{2}(x)$ is the inverse function of $y=2^{x}$.
Also, $y=\log _{10} x$ is the inverse function of $y=10^{x}$.
The graphs of $y=2^{x}$ and $y=\log _{2}(x)$ reflect in the line $x=y$.

## Section 12.11 Problem-solving with exponential and log functions

As stated already, exponential and log functions are used to model a wide variety of problems.
The loudness of sounds, the acidity of a solution and the intensity of earthquakes on the Richter scale are some examples, among many, of their application.

## Example 1

The acidity of a substance is determined by the ion concentration formula $\mathrm{pH}=-\log \left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$, where a pH of 7 is defined as neutral, $<7$ acidic, $>7$ alkaline. Determine the acidity of each of the following substances.
(a) Apple juice with a $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$ion concentration of 0.0003 .
(b) Ammonia with a $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$ion concentration of $1.3 \times 10^{-9}$.
(a) $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]=0.0003 \Rightarrow \mathrm{pH}=-\log \left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\log [0.0003] \\
& =3.52 \quad \therefore \quad \text { the apple juice is acidic }
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) $\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]=1.3 \times 10^{-9} \Rightarrow \mathrm{pH}=-\log \left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\log \left[1.3 \times 10^{-9}\right] \\
& =8.87 \quad \therefore \quad \text { the ammonia solution is alkaline }
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 2

The loudness of a sound of intensity $I$ is given by the formula $\mathrm{dB}=10 \log \left(\frac{I}{I_{\mathrm{o}}}\right)$, where dB is measured in decibels and $I_{\mathrm{o}}$ is the threshold intensity of hearing ( $I_{\mathrm{o}}=1 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{Wm}^{-2}$ ).
(a) Find the loudness (in decibels) of a sound at the threshold of hearing.
(b) Given that prolonged exposure to sounds over 85 decibels can cause hearing damage, and that a gunshot from a .22 rifle has an intensity of $I=2.5 \times 10^{13} I_{\mathrm{o}}$, should you wear ear protection when firing this gun?
(a) Threshold of hearing $=1 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{Wm}^{-2}$
$\mathrm{dB}=10 \log \left(\frac{I}{I_{\mathrm{o}}}\right)=10 \log \left(\frac{1 \times 10^{-12}}{1 \times 10^{-12}}\right)=10 \log 1=0 \mathrm{~dB}$, i.e. no loudness.
(b) $I=2.5 \times 10^{13} I_{\mathrm{o}}$
$\mathrm{dB}=10 \log \left(\frac{I}{I_{\mathrm{o}}}\right)=10 \log \frac{2.5 \times 10^{13} I_{\mathrm{o}}}{I_{\mathrm{o}}}=10 \log 2.5 \times 10^{13}=134 \mathrm{~dB}$.
Yes, since the loudness is well above 85 dB , you should wear ear protection.

## Compound interest (increasing value)

The final value, €A, of a sum of money, € P , invested at a rate of $i$ (expressed in decimal form) compound interest for $t$ years, is given by the formula $\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{P}(1+i)^{t}$. It is often required that we calculate the time, $t$ (the index), for a particular investment to mature. This can be done by using logs as follows;

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { If } \quad \mathrm{A}=\mathrm{P}(1+i)^{t}, \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\mathrm{~A}}{\mathrm{P}}=(1+i)^{t} \ldots \text { dividing both sides by } \mathrm{P} \\
& \Rightarrow \ln \left(\frac{\mathrm{~A}}{\mathrm{P}}\right)=\ln (1+i)^{t} \ldots \text { taking the natural } \log \text { of both sides } \\
& \Rightarrow \ln \left(\frac{\mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{P}}\right)=t \cdot \ln (1+i) \ldots \ln ^{n}=n \cdot \ln \mathrm{~B} \\
& \Rightarrow \frac{\ln \left(\frac{\mathrm{~A}}{\mathrm{P}}\right)}{\ln (1+i)}=t
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 3

How long would it take $€ 5000$ to increase in value to €6000, if invested in a credit union at a yearly compound interest rate of $2 \%$ ?

Since $\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{P}(1+i)^{t}$, where $€ \mathrm{P}$ is invested for $t$ years at $i \%$,

$$
\begin{array}{rlr}
\mathrm{A}=€ 6000 & \quad \mathrm{P}=€ 5000 & i=2 \%=0.02 \quad \therefore \quad 1+i=1.02 \\
\Rightarrow € 6000 & =€ 5000(1.02)^{t} & \quad \text { Method } 2 \\
\frac{6000}{5000} & =(1.02)^{t} & \quad \begin{aligned}
1.2=(1.02)^{t} & \\
1.2 & =(1.02)^{t}
\end{aligned} \\
\ln 1.2 & =\ln (1.02)^{t} \quad \ldots \quad \log _{(1.02)} 1.2=t \\
\ln 1.2 & =t . \ln 1.02 & \Rightarrow t=9.2069=9.21 \text { years. } \\
\frac{\ln 1.2}{\ln 1.02} & =t & \\
9.21 \text { years } & =t \cong 9 \text { years and } 77 \text { days } &
\end{array}
$$

## Depreciation (reducing value)

If a quantity reduces by a fixed amount over a given term (e.g. per annum), the same equation can be adapted to track the reducing value over time.

The present population P then becomes $\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{P}_{0}(1-i)^{t}$ where $\mathrm{P}_{0}$ was the initial population.
For example, if the population of red squirrels is reducing at a rate of $5 \%$ per year, then $\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{P}_{0}(1-0.05)^{t}=\mathrm{P}_{0}(0.95)^{t}$ is the number of red squirrels after " $t$ " years.

## Example 4

The population of red squirrels in a given region was estimated to be 5000 at the start of 2003. Assuming a rate of decrease of $5 \%$ per year, estimate the size of the population in 2013.

Since $\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{P}_{0}(1-i)^{t}$ and $i=5 \%=0.05$, and given that $\mathrm{P}_{0}=5000$ and $t=10$ years,
$\therefore \quad P=5000(1-0.05)^{10}=5000(0.95)^{10}=2994$ squirrels

## Doubling time

The doubling time is the time required for a quantity to double in size or value.
If a quantity is growing exponentially, then the number (or value) present at time $t$ can be expressed by $y=A . e^{b t}$, where $A$ is the amount or value at the start (i.e. $t=0$ ) and $b$ is a growth constant, specific to a particular organism.

If this quantity doubles in size, then there are $2 A$ present.
$\therefore \quad 2 A=A e^{b T}$, where $T$ is the time taken to produce $2 A$, i.e. the doubling time.
$\therefore \quad 2=e^{b T}$
$\therefore \quad \ln 2=\ln e^{b T}=b T \ln e=b T$
$\Rightarrow \frac{\ln 2}{b}=T$, the doubling time.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \qquad \ln x^{n}=n \cdot \ln x \\
& \text { and } \ln e=1
\end{aligned}
$$

## Example 5

A certain type of bacteria is growing exponentially, where $y=\mathrm{A} e^{b t}$ is the number of bacteria present after $t$ (hours) and $b$ is the growth constant. Under certain conditions, the bacteria doubles in population every 6.5 hours. If at the start of the experiment under these conditions there are 100 bacteria present, find (i) the growth constant $b$ (ii) how many bacteria will be present after 2 days.

Since $y=\mathrm{A} e^{b t}$, then $200=100 e^{6.5 b} \ldots$ since 100 doubles to 200 in 6.5 hours

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad 2 & =e^{6.5 b} \\
\therefore \quad \ln 2 & =\ln e^{6.5 b}=6.5 b \ln e=6.5 b
\end{aligned}
$$

(i) The growth constant $b=\frac{\ln 2}{6.5}=0.1066$ per hour.
(ii) Two days $=48$ hours

The number present after 48 hours $=100 e^{0.1066 \times 48}$

$$
=16680 \text { bacteria. }
$$

## Section 12.12 Proofs by induction

Many theorems in mathematics are proven true using the method of mathematical induction.
To prove a statement true by induction, we follow clearly-defined steps.
(i) The statement is proven true for some fixed value, usually $n=1$ or $n=2$.
(ii) The statement is then assumed true for $n=k$.
(iii) Based on this assumption, we must show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.
(iv) In conclusion, a "rolling proof" is formed:
a. Since it was true for $n=1$,
b. it is now true for $n=1+1=2$.
c. Since it is true for $n=2$, it is true for $n=2+1=3$, etc.
d. It is therefore true for all values of $n$.

## Example 1

Prove that for all values of $\boldsymbol{n}, 1+2+3+4+\ldots n=\frac{n}{2}(n+1)$.

## Proof:

(i) Prove the statement true for $n=1$.

$$
\Rightarrow 1=\frac{1}{2}(1+1)=\frac{1}{2}(2)=1, \text { which is true. }
$$

(ii) Assume true for $n=k$.

$$
\Rightarrow 1+2+3+4+\ldots k=\frac{k}{2}(k+1) .
$$

(iii) Based on this assumption, we must show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+2+3+4+\ldots k+(\boldsymbol{k}+\mathbf{1}) & =\frac{k}{2}(k+1)+(\boldsymbol{k}+\mathbf{1}) \ldots \text { adding }(k+1) \text { to } \\
& =(k+1)\left(\frac{k}{2}+1\right) \ldots \text { factorising }(k+1) \\
& =(k+1)\left(\frac{k+2}{2}\right) \ldots \text { getting a common } \\
& =\left(\frac{k+1}{2}\right)(k+2) \ldots \text { re-arranging the } \\
& =\left(\frac{k+1}{2}\right)[(k+1)+1]
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad$ It is true for $n=k+1$.
(iv) But since it is true for $n=1$, it now must be true for $n=1+1=2$.

And if it is true for $n=2$, it is true for $n=2+1=3 \ldots$ etc.
(v) Therefore, it is true for all values of $n$.

Note 1: Although we could prove this statement true for many discrete values of $n$, the important feature of this method of proof is that it proves the statement true for all values of $\boldsymbol{n}$.

Note 2: Mathematical induction is not a means of discovering a result, but when we have a result that seems to be true, this method provides us with a rigorous proof.

Note 3: Proof by induction can be applied to several different categories of results including;
(i) Results involving series of numbers e.g. $1+2+3+4+\ldots . n=\frac{n}{2}(n+1)$.
(ii) Results involving factors of expressions
e.g. $10^{n}-7^{n}$ is divisible by 3 .
(iii) Results involving inequalities
e.g. $3^{n}>3 n+1$, for $n \geqslant 2$.

## Example 2

Prove that for all values of $n \in N, 3+3^{2}+3^{3}+3^{4}+3^{5}+\ldots .3^{n}=\frac{3}{2}\left(3^{n}-1\right)$.

## Proof:

(i) Prove the statement true for $n=1$.

$$
3^{1}=\frac{3}{2}\left(3^{1}-1\right)=\frac{3}{2}(2)=3 \ldots \text { which is true. }
$$

(ii) Assume true for $n=k$.

$$
3+3^{2}+3^{3}+3^{4}+3^{5}+\ldots 3^{k}=\frac{3}{2}\left(3^{k}-1\right)
$$

(iii) Based on this assumption, we must now show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
3+3^{2}+3^{3}+3^{4}+3^{5}+\ldots 3^{k}+\mathbf{3}^{k+1} & =\frac{3}{2}\left(3^{k}-1\right)+\mathbf{3}^{k+1} \ldots \text { adding } 3^{k+1} \\
& =\frac{3}{2}\left(3^{k}-1\right)+3^{k} \cdot 3^{1} \\
& =3\left(\frac{\left(3^{k}-1\right)}{2}+3^{k}\right) \ldots \text { factorising } 3 . \\
& =3\left(\frac{3^{k}-1+2.3^{k}}{2}\right) \ldots \text { common } \\
& =\frac{3}{2}\left(3.3^{k}-1\right) \ldots \text { rearranging. } \\
& =\frac{3}{2}\left(3^{k+1}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad$ It is true for $n=k+1$.
(iv) But since it is true for $n=1$, it now must be true for $n=1+1=2$.

And if it is true for $n=2$, it is true for $n=2+1=3 \ldots$ etc.
(v) Therefore, it is true for all values of $n$.

## Example 3

Prove by induction that $\frac{1}{1.2}+\frac{1}{2.3}+\frac{1}{3.4}+\ldots \frac{1}{n(n+1)}=\frac{n}{n+1}, n \in N$.

## Proof:

(i) Prove the statement true for $n=1$.

$$
\frac{1}{1(1+1)}=\frac{1}{1+1}=\frac{1}{2} \ldots \text { which is true. }
$$

(ii) Assume true for $n=k$.

$$
\frac{1}{1.2}+\frac{1}{2.3}+\frac{1}{3.4}+\ldots \frac{1}{k(k+1)}=\frac{k}{k+1}, k \in N .
$$

(iii) Based on this assumption, we must now show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{1.2}+\frac{1}{2.3}+\frac{1}{3.4}+\ldots \frac{1}{k(k+1)}+\frac{\mathbf{1}}{(\boldsymbol{k}+\mathbf{1})(\boldsymbol{k}+\mathbf{2})} & =\frac{k}{k+1}+\frac{\mathbf{1}}{(\boldsymbol{k}+\mathbf{1})(\boldsymbol{k}+\mathbf{2})} \\
& =\frac{k(k+2)+1}{(k+1)(k+2)} \\
& =\frac{k^{2}+2 k+1}{(k+1)(k+2)} \\
=\frac{(k+1)(k+1)}{(k+1)(k+2)} & =\frac{(k+1)}{(k+1)+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad$ It is true for $n=k+1$.
(iv) But since it is true for $n=1$, it now must be true for $n=1+1=2$.

And if it is true for $n=2$, it is true for $n=2+1=3, \ldots$ etc.
(v) Therefore, it is true for all values of $n$.

## Divisibility proofs

## Example 4

Prove that for all $n \in N, 3$ is a factor of $4^{n}-1$.

## Proof:

(i) Prove the statement true for $n=1$.

3 is a factor of $4^{1}-1=3 \ldots$ true.
(ii) Assume true for $n=k$.
$\Rightarrow 3$ is a factor of $4^{k}-1, k \in N$.
(iii) Based on this assumption, we must now show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.

Is 3 a factor of $4^{k+1}-1$ ?

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4^{k} \cdot 4^{1}-1 \\
& =4^{k} \cdot(3+1)-1 \\
& =3 \cdot 4^{k}+1 \cdot 4^{k}-1 \\
& =3 \cdot 4^{k}+\left(4^{k}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $3.4^{k}$ is divisible by 3 and ( $4^{k}-1$ ) is assumed divisible by 3 ,
$\therefore \quad 3.4^{k}+\left(4^{k}-1\right)$ is divisible by 3 .
$\therefore \quad$ It is true for $n=k+1$.
(iv) But since it is true for $n=1$, it now must be true for $n=1+1=2$.

And if it is true for $n=2$, it is true for $n=2+1=3, \ldots$ etc.
(v) Therefore, it is true for all values of $n$.

## Example 5

Prove by induction that $8^{n}-7 n+6$ is divisible by 7 for all $n \in N$.

## Proof:

(i) Prove the statement true for $n=1$.

7 is a factor of $8^{1}-7.1+6=7 \ldots$ which is true.
(ii) Assume true for $n=k$.

$$
\Rightarrow 7 \text { is a factor of } 8^{k}-7 k+6, k \in N .
$$

(iii) Based on this assumption, we must now show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.

Is 7 a factor of $8^{k+1}-7(k+1)+6$ ?

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =8^{k} \cdot 8^{1}-7 k-7+6 \\
& =8^{k} \cdot(7+1)-7 k-7+6 \\
& =7 \cdot 8^{k}+1.8^{k}-7 k-7+6 \\
& =7 \cdot 8^{k}+\left(8^{k}-7 k+6\right)-7
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $7.8^{k}$ is divisible by 7 , ( $8^{k}-7 k+6$ ) is assumed divisible by 7 and -7 is divisible by 7 ,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad 8^{k+1}-7(k+1)+6 \text { is divisible by } 7 . \\
& \therefore \quad \text { It is true for } n=k+1 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(iv) But since it is true for $n=1$, it now must be true for $n=1+1=2$.

And if it is true for $n=2$, it is true for $n=2+1=3, \ldots$ etc.
(v) Therefore, it is true for all values of $n$.

## Example 6

Show that $n(n+1)(n+2)$ is divisible by 3 for $n \in N$.

## Proof:

(i) Prove the statement true for $n=1$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
3 \text { is a factor of } n(n+1)(n+2) & =1(1+1)(1+2) \\
& =6 \ldots \text { which is true. }
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) Assume true for $n=k$.

$$
\Rightarrow 3 \text { is a factor of } k(k+1)(k+2), k \in N
$$

(iii) Based on this assumption, we must now show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.

Is 3 a factor of $(\boldsymbol{k}+\mathbf{1})(\boldsymbol{k}+\mathbf{1}+1)(\boldsymbol{k}+\mathbf{1}+2)$ ?

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =(k+1)(k+2)[k+3] \\
& =(k+1)(k+2) k+(k+1)(k+2) 3 \\
& =k(k+1)(k+2)+3(k+1)(k+2)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since 3 is assumed a factor of $k(k+1)(k+2)$, and 3 is a factor of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3(k+1)(k+2) \\
& \therefore \quad(k+1)(k+2)(k+3) \text { is divisible by } 3 . \\
& \therefore \quad \text { It is true for } n=k+1 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(iv) But since it is true for $n=1$, it now must be true for $n=1+1=2$.

And if it is true for $n=2$, it is true for $n=2+1=3, \ldots$ etc.
(v) Therefore, it is true for all values of $n$.

## Inequality proofs

When dealing with inequalities we noted two important deductions, namely
(i) If $a>b$, then $a-b>0$
(ii) $(\text { any real number })^{2}>0$.

## Example 7

Prove by induction that $2^{n}>n^{2}$ for $n \geqslant 5, n \in N$.

## Proof:

(i) Prove the statement true for $n=5$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2^{5}>5^{2} \\
& 32>25 \ldots \text { which is true. }
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) Assume true for $n=k, k \geqslant 5$.

$$
\Rightarrow 2^{k}>k^{2}, k \in N \text { and } k \geqslant 5 .
$$

(iii) Based on this assumption, we must now show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.

$$
\text { Is } \quad 2^{k+1}>(k+1)^{2} \text { ? }
$$

Since $2^{k}>k^{2}$ (assumed)

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & 2^{k} \cdot 2>2 k^{2} \\
\therefore & 2^{k+1}>2 k^{2}
\end{array}
$$

$\therefore \quad$ we need to prove that $2 k^{2}>(k+1)^{2}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 k^{2}>k^{2}+2 k+1 \\
& k^{2}-2 k-1>0 \\
& k^{2}-2 k+\mathbf{1}-\mathbf{1}-1>0 \quad \ldots \text { completing the square by adding and } \\
& k^{2}-2 k+1-2>0 \quad \text { subtracting half the coefficient of } k \text { squared. } \\
(k-1)^{2}-2 & >0 \quad \text { which is true for } k \geqslant 5 . \\
\therefore \quad & 2^{k+1}>2 k^{2}>(k+1)^{2} \\
\therefore \quad & \text { It is true for } n=k+1 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(iv) But since it is true for $n=5$, it now must be true for $n=5+1=6$.

And if it is true for $n=6$, it is true for $n=6+1=7$, ... etc.
(v) Therefore, it is true for all values of $n \geqslant 5, n \in N$.

## Example 8

Prove by induction that $n!>2^{n}, n \geqslant 4, n \in N$.

## Proof:

(i) Prove the statement true for $n=4$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
4! & >2^{4} \\
24 & >16 \ldots \text { which is true. }
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) Assume true for $n=k, k \geqslant 4$.

$$
\Rightarrow k!>2^{k}, k \in N \text { and } k \geqslant 4 .
$$

(iii) Based on this assumption, we must now show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Is }(k+1)!>2^{k+1} \text { ? } \\
& \text { Is }(k+1) k!>2^{k} \cdot 2 \text { ? } \ldots(k+1) k!=(k+1) \text { ! }
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $k!>2^{k}$ (assumed),
$\therefore \quad(k+1) k!>(k+1) 2^{k}$
$\therefore \quad$ we need to prove that $(k+1) 2^{k}>2^{k} .2$
$(k+1) 2^{k}>2.2^{k}$ which is obviously true if $k>1$.

$$
\therefore(k+1)!>2^{k+1}
$$

$\therefore \quad$ It is true for $n=k+1$.
(iv) But since it is true for $n=4$, it now must be true for $n=4+1=5$.

And if it is true for $n=5$, it is true for $n=5+1=6, \ldots$ etc.
(v) Therefore, it is true for all values of $n \geqslant 4, n \in N$.

## Example 9

Prove that $(1+x)^{n} \geqslant 1+n x$ for $n \geqslant 1, n \in N, x \in R$.

## Proof:

(i) Prove the statement true for $n=1$.

$$
\Rightarrow(1+x)^{1} \geqslant 1+1 \cdot x \ldots \text { which is true. }
$$

(ii) Assume true for $n=k, k \geqslant 1$.

$$
(1+x)^{k} \geqslant 1+k x, k \in N \text { and } k \geqslant 1 .
$$

(iii) Based on this assumption, we must now show that the statement is true for $n=k+1$.

$$
\text { Is }(1+x)^{k+1} \geqslant 1+(k+1) x \text { ? }
$$

$$
\text { Is }(1+x)^{k}(1+x) \geqslant 1+k x+x \text { ? }
$$

Since $(1+x)^{k} \geqslant 1+k x \ldots$ (assumed).

$$
\therefore \quad(1+x)^{k}(1+x) \geqslant(1+k x)(1+x)
$$

$\therefore \quad$ we need to prove that $(1+k x)(1+x) \geqslant 1+k x+x$

$$
1+x+k x+k x^{2} \geqslant 1+k x+x
$$

$\Rightarrow k x^{2} \geqslant 0$ which is true for $k \geqslant 1$ and $x \in R$.
$\therefore$ It is true for $n=k+1$.
(iv) But since it is true for $n=1$, it now must be true for $n=1+1=2$.

And if it is true for $n=2$, it is true for $n=2+1=3, \ldots$ etc.
(v) Therefore, it is true for all values of $n \geqslant 1, n \in N$.

2 a^{2}-3 a+1=0 .
